urn:contentItem:5X3C-C371-JCMN-Y2NC-00000-00Facebook to Launch 'Independent Supreme Court' Body to Monitor Its Content2019-09-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:35ZLexisNexisFacebook to Launch 'Independent Supreme Court' Body to Monitor Its ContentActivist Post

Sep 20, 2019( Activist Post: http://www.activistpost.com Delivered by Newstex) ;   https://www.activistpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Facebook_Spying.jpgBy Makia Freeman[1] THE STORY: On September 17th 2019, Facebook released a charter for a new Oversight Board to moderate its content, known colloquially by some as the Facebook Independent Supreme Court. THE IMPLICATIONS: How independent will this board really be? What are Facebook's true motivations for setting up this board?

Given the past history of fact checking and censorship, will this Independent Supreme Court become just another censoring authority?What's behind the Facebook Independent Supreme Court?Facebook has announced[2] the formation of a new Oversight Board which will be in charge of content moderation on the social media giant's platform. The new body was known previously and colloquially as the Facebook Independent Supreme Court. This nickname is apt for many reasons. Facebook is not a private company but a quasi-governmental organization, and I use the word 'quasi' very generously in this context. Facebook has a background of accepting Military Intelligence seed money. Its suspicious inception date suggests it is a continuation of DARPA's LifeLog surveillance program[3]. Like many big companies in the corporatocracy, FB has a revolving door at the top, accepting many former government officials (like Nick Clegg quoted below) into senior management positions. Then, there is its cozy relationship with the Atlantic Council, which is in turn funded by the US Government and is connected to NATO. Facebook unveiled the plan for the board which includes giving it the power to moderate all content - including presumably the ability to demote, censor and ban. But how independent will this board be? What does this mean for free speech and censorship? The Composition of the Facebook Independent Supreme CourtThis Oversight Board will be funded by another body (the Facebook Trust). Initially, Facebook will be doing everything: funding the Trust, choosing the trustees of the Trust and placing all the initial 11 members on the Oversight Board. Independent, you may ask? RT reports: Facebook insists it is 'committed to selecting a diverse and qualified group' - no current or former Facebook employees or spouses thereof, current government officials or lobbyists (former[4] ones are apparently OK), high-ranking officials within political parties (low-ranking is apparently cool), or significant shareholders of Facebook need apply. A law firm will be employed to vet candidates for conflicts of interest, but given Facebook's apparent inability to recognize the conflict of interest inherent in paying 'independent' board members to make binding content decisions, it's hard to tell what would qualify as a conflict.Setting an Industry Standard for Content Moderation, i.e. CensorshipFacebook has been under scrutiny and pressure for years now, especially for its disregard and invasion of privacy, as well as its perceived violation of anti-trust law. CEO Zuckerberg even called for Congress to regulate FB. This move is likely an attempt to self-regulate in the hopes that it avoids heavy-handed governmental regulation. Former British politician and now VP Global Affairs and Communications, Nick Clegg, wrote that the 'Oversight Board will make Facebook more accountable and improve our decision-making This charter is a critical step towards what we hope will become a model for our industry.' Is this Facebook Independent Supreme Court yet another attempt (alongside organizations like the Soros-linked International Fact Checking Network[5], and the Neocon and Atlantic Council-linked NewsGuard[6]) to set up some kind of authoritative body who decides what is true and false, right and wrong, allowed and disallowed for every single online user? Will they begin to 'rule by precedent' in banning certain kinds of speech? How much chance will a small average user have to appeal? Here is RT again: 'For now,' only Facebook-initiated cases will be heard by the board - Facebook users will be able to launch their own appeals by mid-2020 Decisions will not only be binding, but also applicable to other cases not being heard, if they're deemed similar enough - potentially opening a Pandora's box of far-reaching censorship. All the Big Tech giants are trying new ad transparency measures; however, it may mostly be for show, as the article Facebook's New 'Supreme Court' Could Revolutionize Online Speech[7] highlights: Facebook, Google, and Twitter have all recently unveiled ad transparency measures; meanwhile the proposed Honest Ads Act, which would compel these sorts of disclosures, has made little progress in Congress. This is despite extensive[8] reporting [9]about[10] weaknesses in Facebook's ad transparency tools. https://thefreedomarticles.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/facebook-privacy.jpgFacebook privacy. A contradiction in terms. Rather than making you read the whole guide, I'll sum it up in 3 words: YOU HAVE NONE. Trying to Shift the Censorship BuckIt would be a PR victory for Facebook if it could blame censorship (or in Orwellian language 'difficult content moderation decisions') on an outside and supposedly independent board. The same article describes Facebook's motivations here: There is also the user-relations dimension. When Zuckerberg first floated the idea in April, I analogized Zuckerberg's desire for restraint to the voluntarily segregated hotels and restaurants that counterintuitively supported anti-discrimination legislation during the Civil Rights Movement. They did so because they would earn more profits if they provided their services to everyone, but would pay a social cost in their white communities if they decided to voluntarily stop discriminating. Content moderation decisions on Facebook are hard and any call is likely to upset a proportion of Facebook users. By outsourcing the decision and blame, Facebook can try to wash its hands of controversial decisions.Final ThoughtsFacebook has become the data mining and surveillance arm of the New World Order. Zuckerberg called the people 'dumb fucks'[11] who handed over their personal information to Facebook early on. Earlier this year, Facebook's lawyers[12] argued that Facebook users have no 'reasonable expectation of privacy.' At one point, Facebook promoted the idea of an internet driver's license[13] and wanted to be the one to supply unique internet IDs - just to ensure the tracking and tracing of society went even further. There was the 2018 Cambridge Analytica scandal where that company harvested the personal and psychographic data from millions of peoples' FB profiles without their consent to used it for political advertising. Just recently, smart TVs were caught sending sensitive user data to Facebook[14]. The scandals truly never end for this privacy-destroying, free-speech squashing, military-intelligence-government-linked company. A Facebook Independent Supreme Court? Don't expect it to be anything other than another tool of censorship and control.Makia Freeman is the editor of alternative media / independent newssiteThe Freedom Articles[15]and senior researcher atToolsForFreedom.com[16]. urn:contentItem:5XF5-1CP1-JDJN-610D-00000-00Facebook to launch Libra – are we geared for the challenge2019-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:34ZLexisNexisFacebook to launch Libra – are we geared for the challengeGeorge M Mangion

Research carried out last year by the Central Bank of Malta indicated that cards are more popular than cheques as an alternative to cash. It also confirmed that although the use of modern methods of payments such as cards has increased, cash remains the preferred way to pay for groceries, consumables, non-consumables, utility bills and wellness services.

So although there is a marked increase in online payments, direct debits and prepaid cards, cash still rules the roost. It stands to reason that this high percentage of cash transactions leads to a greater propensity for tax evasion (essentially in VAT). This is confirmed by a recent Eurostat report which reveals that Malta suffers from the highest percentage of tax leakage in Europe. Its revenue loss due to evasion in 2016 amounted to a cool €230 million or 2.39 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).

The question that follows is: can the encouragement of a more cash-less society mitigate this haemorrhage of tax revenue loss? As an illustration, some Asian countries have been cash-less for many years and people use their mobile phones for everyday purchases. This includes micro payments such as buying newspapers, bus journeys, coffee or tea from cafeterias, etc. Perhaps the quiet revolution to switch to cash-less payments will hit Malta early next year when (and if) Facebook succeeds in its revolutionary coin - called 'Libra'.

Some brand this coin as a 'cryptocurrency' and if this is true, then Malta is well poised to regulate it. It also spent millions to launch Blockchain and DLT concepts when it actively sponsored Delta Summits and Sigma events. Some argue that, once launched, Libra will be good for the crypto industry while others dislike the fact that Facebook - being a big tech company - appears to be riding roughshod on a DL0T technology that is still not globally regulated.

The vagaries of Bitcoin values in the market have troubled many investors and those who speculated in its future ascent have burnt their fingers. In addition, accusations that Bitcoin began its trajectory as an anonymous currency habitually used by extortionists and drug cartels have certainly tarnished its image. So far, one may observe that many much-hyped blockchain projects have failed to meet expectations and, despite several attempts, few have been able to convince mainstream consumers to use cryptocurrency to pay for daily purchases.

Back to Libra coin. It will run on a blockchain, but it will be a far cry from Bitcoin. It has the ambitious goal of bringing financial services to the 1.7 billion people around the world who still do not have bank accounts. It also proudly offers to let users buy items - or send money to others - with nearly zero fees.

To begin with, it will not be a purely digital asset with fluctuating value but will be engineered to maintain a stable value. In theory, it will also be fully backed with a basket of bank deposits and treasuries lodged with high-quality central banks.

Back to Bitcoin - a unique advantage of using its network is that it is public, meaning that it can be used by anyone with an internet connection. It can run the network's software, and help validate new transactions. In fact, armed with a powerful computer, devotees can even mine fresh coins by adding new transactions to the chain. In sheer comparison, Libra's network is different since it will be running a 'validator node' that requires permission.

At the outset, Facebook wanted to have a syndicate of operators so it has signed up a number of collaborators such as Lyft, Spotify and Vodafone to participate in the network - each of which has invested around $10 million in the project - to validate transactions.

The drawback to Libra when compared to crypto currencies is that Libra networks are more vulnerable due to the centralisation of power and higher vulnerability from hackers to attack the network. Libra blockchain is not decentralised in the way Bitcoin is. Libra's nodes will be only run from the servers of the Libra Association.

Bitcoins use a more decentralised technology which makes them extremely difficult and expensive to manipulate transaction records in such networks. On the other hand, public blockchains use too much power and, in the advent of a global drive to lower CO² emissions from power stations, this is not welcome and is probably the biggest obstacle to the global adoption of cryptocurrencies. According to the Libra white paper, its system will be able to process 1,000 transactions per second, much faster than Bitcoin, which can only process a handful per second.

Quoting David Marcus, who has overseen the Libra project for Facebook, he reveals that financial and social data will not be "commingled," and that users can keep their digital wallets separate from their Facebook profiles. He also said that Libra's involvement would be handled through a software 'wallet' subsidiary called Calibra, registered in Switzerland. This company will store user funds and act as an initial on-ramp to the Libra coin.

Critics say that Libra's marketing blast and its big razzamatazz song is simply a smokescreen to offset the firm's appalling record on data privacy. Can Libra users demand that the currency be more decentralised and tamper-proofed?

Another obstacle is the resistance to Libra from major countries in Europe such as France and Germany, who want to block it - accusing it of challenging the 'monetary sovereignty' of governments.

Others say that Libra is a surreptitious plot to fish for our data, mostly targeting our financial and health status. Many are sceptical of future monopolistic abuse of the dominant position enjoyed by Facebook. Another hurdle is the tax leakage following millions of Libra transactions if and when this goes mainstream. If all goes well, perhaps Father Christmas will surprise us with gifts of Libra coin stuffed in our season's gifts and hampers.

urn:contentItem:5Y50-TK71-F11P-X4T2-00000-00Facebook to launch Libra – are we geared for the challenge2019-11-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:34ZLexisNexisFacebook to launch Libra – are we geared for the challengeGeorge M Mangion

Research carried out last year by the Central Bank of Malta indicated that cards are more popular than cheques as an alternative to cash. It also confirmed that although the use of modern methods of payments such as cards has increased, cash remains the preferred way to pay for groceries, consumables, non-consumables, utility bills and wellness services.

So although there is a marked increase in online payments, direct debits and prepaid cards, cash still rules the roost. It stands to reason that this high percentage of cash transactions leads to a greater propensity for tax evasion (essentially in VAT). This is confirmed by a recent Eurostat report which reveals that Malta suffers from the highest percentage of tax leakage in Europe. Its revenue loss due to evasion in 2016 amounted to a cool €230 million or 2.39 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP).

The question that follows is: can the encouragement of a more cash-less society mitigate this haemorrhage of tax revenue loss? As an illustration, some Asian countries have been cash-less for many years and people use their mobile phones for everyday purchases. This includes micro payments such as buying newspapers, bus journeys, coffee or tea from cafeterias, etc. Perhaps the quiet revolution to switch to cash-less payments will hit Malta early next year when (and if) Facebook succeeds in its revolutionary coin - called 'Libra'.

Some brand this coin as a 'cryptocurrency' and if this is true, then Malta is well poised to regulate it. It also spent millions to launch Blockchain and DLT concepts when it actively sponsored Delta Summits and Sigma events. Some argue that, once launched, Libra will be good for the crypto industry while others dislike the fact that Facebook - being a big tech company - appears to be riding roughshod on a DL0T technology that is still not globally regulated.

The vagaries of Bitcoin values in the market have troubled many investors and those who speculated in its future ascent have burnt their fingers. In addition, accusations that Bitcoin began its trajectory as an anonymous currency habitually used by extortionists and drug cartels have certainly tarnished its image. So far, one may observe that many much-hyped blockchain projects have failed to meet expectations and, despite several attempts, few have been able to convince mainstream consumers to use cryptocurrency to pay for daily purchases.

Back to Libra coin. It will run on a blockchain, but it will be a far cry from Bitcoin. It has the ambitious goal of bringing financial services to the 1.7 billion people around the world who still do not have bank accounts. It also proudly offers to let users buy items - or send money to others - with nearly zero fees.

To begin with, it will not be a purely digital asset with fluctuating value but will be engineered to maintain a stable value. In theory, it will also be fully backed with a basket of bank deposits and treasuries lodged with high-quality central banks.

Back to Bitcoin - a unique advantage of using its network is that it is public, meaning that it can be used by anyone with an internet connection. It can run the network's software, and help validate new transactions. In fact, armed with a powerful computer, devotees can even mine fresh coins by adding new transactions to the chain. In sheer comparison, Libra's network is different since it will be running a 'validator node' that requires permission.

At the outset, Facebook wanted to have a syndicate of operators so it has signed up a number of collaborators such as Lyft, Spotify and Vodafone to participate in the network - each of which has invested around $10 million in the project - to validate transactions.

The drawback to Libra when compared to crypto currencies is that Libra networks are more vulnerable due to the centralisation of power and higher vulnerability from hackers to attack the network. Libra blockchain is not decentralised in the way Bitcoin is. Libra's nodes will be only run from the servers of the Libra Association.

Bitcoins use a more decentralised technology which makes them extremely difficult and expensive to manipulate transaction records in such networks. On the other hand, public blockchains use too much power and, in the advent of a global drive to lower CO² emissions from power stations, this is not welcome and is probably the biggest obstacle to the global adoption of cryptocurrencies. According to the Libra white paper, its system will be able to process 1,000 transactions per second, much faster than Bitcoin, which can only process a handful per second.

Quoting David Marcus, who has overseen the Libra project for Facebook, he reveals that financial and social data will not be "commingled," and that users can keep their digital wallets separate from their Facebook profiles. He also said that Libra's involvement would be handled through a software 'wallet' subsidiary called Calibra, registered in Switzerland. This company will store user funds and act as an initial on-ramp to the Libra coin.

Critics say that Libra's marketing blast and its big razzamatazz song is simply a smokescreen to offset the firm's appalling record on data privacy. Can Libra users demand that the currency be more decentralised and tamper-proofed?

Another obstacle is the resistance to Libra from major countries in Europe such as France and Germany, who want to block it - accusing it of challenging the 'monetary sovereignty' of governments.

Others say that Libra is a surreptitious plot to fish for our data, mostly targeting our financial and health status. Many are sceptical of future monopolistic abuse of the dominant position enjoyed by Facebook. Another hurdle is the tax leakage following millions of Libra transactions if and when this goes mainstream. If all goes well, perhaps Father Christmas will surprise us with gifts of Libra coin stuffed in our season's gifts and hampers.

George Mangion is a senior partner of an audit and consultancy firm

urn:contentItem:5Y54-T7D1-DXKX-0494-00000-00Facebook to Launch Oversight Board That Exec Says Won't Look Like Silicon Valley2020-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:34ZLexisNexisFacebook to Launch Oversight Board That Exec Says Won't Look Like Silicon Valley

Feb 06, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/Delivered by Newstex) Will Facebook's new oversight board be the platform to ensure free speech or a Big Tech kangaroo court?The site's in-house newsroom posted a developer blog[1] on Jan 28 which announced the platform's upcoming oversight board. While its actual members will be chosen and announced '[i]n the coming months,' Facebook staff did reveal that 'the first Director of Oversight Board Administration will be Thomas Hughes.'

Hughes was described as the 'former Executive Director for Article 19, an international non-governmental organization with a focus on freedom of expression and digital rights' who will 'lead the board's administrative staff.'According to The Verge[2], Hughes claimed the board will ensure that 'the rights of people are respected.' He also claimed that it will ensure 'accountability and transparency in the application of the community standards.'Can conservatives depend on Hughes to defend their personal liberties, or is he merely the token free speech advocate to help protect Facebook from being regulated? Facebook, like other Silicon Valley Big Tech companies, has an 'intolerant[3]' liberal culture, even according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg himself. Can such an openly 'intolerant' company be trusted to hire objective members to be on its oversight board?Facebook Director of Governance and Global Affairs Brent Harris claimed that there will be a diverse range of members overseeing content on Facebook and Instagram. 'Almost any person on the planet may not like one or two people who are on the board, and we think that's a feature,' he commented to reporters. 'When we announce, you're going to see that this isn't just a board that looks like Silicon Valley or looks like Facebook.'While it may seem good on the surface to have diversity -- having multiple cultures and nations represented -- many nations have wildly differing standards[4] on freedom of speech and expression. But Facebook, as an American company, serves human dignity far better by having an U.S. Constitution-centric approach to freedom of speech, rather than one that would hold free speaking western nations and foreign authoritarian regimes as equals.In 2019, tech companies such as Blizzard have been brought to shame[5] by caving to the demands of China and censoring their own users amid rebellion in Hong Kong.The moderation decisions made by the board will cover a range of controversial topics in America and around the world. The Verge noted the following in its coverage:'There are also provisions to ensure local representation, an issue Facebook has struggled with when adjudicating ethnic conflicts in countries like Myanmar and Sri Lanka. According to the bylaws, each case will be decided by a panel consisting of four randomly selected board members and one from the region that's primarily affected.'This program was put in place to ensure the board has 'cultural awareness to nuanced local conflicts,' noted The Verge.Let's just see how culturally aware Silicon Valley-types can be to their own conservative, Christian neighbors. Feb 06, 2020( Newsbusters.org: http://newsbusters.org/ Delivered by Newstex) Will Facebook's new oversight board be the platform to ensure free speech or a Big Tech kangaroo court?The site's in-house newsroom posted a developer blog[1] on Jan 28 which announced the platform's upcoming oversight board. While its actual members will be chosen and announced #8216;[i]n the coming months,#8217; Facebook staff did reveal that #8216;the first Director of Oversight Board Administration will be Thomas Hughes.#8217; Hughes was described as the #8216;former Executive Director for Article 19, an international non-governmental organization with a focus on freedom of expression and digital rights#8217; who will #8216;lead the board's administrative staff.#8217;According to The Verge[2], Hughes claimed the board will ensure that #8216;the rights of people are respected.#8217; He also claimed that it will ensure #8216;accountability and transparency in the application of the community standards.#8217;Can conservatives depend on Hughes to defend their personal liberties, or is he merely the token free speech advocate to help protect Facebook from being regulated?

Facebook, like other Silicon Valley Big Tech companies, has an #8216;intolerant[3]#8217; liberal culture, even according to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg himself. Can such an openly #8216;intolerant#8217; company be trusted to hire objective members to be on its oversight board?Facebook Director of Governance and Global Affairs Brent Harris claimed that there will be a diverse range of members overseeing content on Facebook and Instagram. #8216;Almost any person on the planet may not like one or two people who are on the board, and we think that's a feature,#8217; he commented to reporters. #8216;When we announce, you're going to see that this isn't just a board that looks like Silicon Valley or looks like Facebook.#8217;While it may seem good on the surface to have diversity -- having multiple cultures and nations represented -- many nations have wildly differing standards[4] on freedom of speech and expression. But Facebook, as an American company, serves human dignity far better by having an U.S. Constitution-centric approach to freedom of speech, rather than one that would hold free speaking western nations and foreign authoritarian regimes as equals.In 2019, tech companies such as Blizzard have been brought to shame[5] by caving to the demands of China and censoring their own users amid rebellion in Hong Kong.The moderation decisions made by the board will cover a range of controversial topics in America and around the world. The Verge noted the following in its coverage:#8216;There are also provisions to ensure local representation, an issue Facebook has struggled with when adjudicating ethnic conflicts in countries like Myanmar and Sri Lanka. According to the bylaws, each case will be decided by a panel consisting of four randomly selected board members and one from the region that's primarily affected.#8217;This program was put in place to ensure the board has #8216;cultural awareness to nuanced local conflicts,#8217; noted The Verge.Let's just see how culturally aware Silicon Valley-types can be to their own conservative, Christian neighbors. urn:contentItem:5V8Y-5CK1-F021-6426-00000-00Facebook, too big to unfriend;The sheer scale of the social network allows it to shrug off scandal2019-01-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:35ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:1Facebook, too big to unfriendThe sheer scale of the social network allows it to shrug off scandalDanny Fortson

Facebook's future rests not with Washington regulators or big advertisers but a small band of teenagers. At least that's what the social media giant seems to think. About 100 young people have signed non-disclosure agreements - or, rather, their parents have - while they test a new product Facebook has been quietly working on for months.

LOL, a feed of popular memes grouped under headings such as "Fails", "Pranks" and "Wait for It", is the latest desperate attempt to address what the research firm eMarketer has dubbed Facebook's "teen problem".

Only 51% of US teens say they use Facebook, according to the Pew Research Centre. That is a dramatic fall from 2015, when Pew found Facebook was by far the dominant social network, used by 71% of 13 to 17-year-olds. These days, Snapchat, YouTube and Instagram are all more popular. Just 15 years old, the $420bn social media giant has somehow become tragically uncool.

Facebook's teen problem, however, is a slow burner, an existential challenge overshadowed by pyrotechnic scandals. Last year, Mark Zuckerberg was hauled before Congress and politicians in Brussels over the Cambridge Analytica data-harvesting scandal and Russia's disinformation campaigns. The UN blamed the company for genocide in Burma.

Its shares suffered the biggest one-day collapse in history after it warned of slowing profits. The founders of WhatsApp and Instagram, both acquired by Facebook, left in a huff. Zuckerberg's former mentor Roger McNamee turned on him, writing in a forthcoming book called Zucked that he is "disappointed", "embarrassed" and "ashamed" for helping to create the social media monster.

The Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the US watchdog, is close to handing down a $22m (£16.7m) fine over privacy failings, and Congress is preparing a data protection crackdown that could be passed this year. The question of where Facebook goes next must be answered with two very different timelines - one more immediate, the other longer-term.

Zuckerberg's empire has so far shown itself virtually impervious to scandal, as will be displayed on Wednesday when the 34-year-old billionaire announces its annual results. By any measure, they will be fantastic. Consensus net income for 2018 is $21.6bn, a 36% increase on the year, with sales also up 36% to $55bn.

The investment bank JP Morgan said that, far from stumbling, Facebook had reached "rarefied air" and is "still early in the development of its ad platform".

Sheer scale is Facebook's saving grace. Between Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram, the company's products are used by 2.6bn people - a third of the planet. The precision with which advertisers can target audiences creates a powerful combination that won't easily be overturned.

Last week it emerged Zuckerberg is working on plans to merge Instagram, Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp into a single messaging colossus. The front end of the apps - the interfaces used by consumers - would not change. Yet integrating the underlying infrastructure could offer a powerful new way for brands to reach people. The move could also raise competition concerns.

Yet there are other factors at work that will slow the Facebook machine. The biggest is security. Last year's events showed its privacy and safety controls to be woeful. In response, Zuckerberg pledged to hire 30,000 staff to filter out abusive and dodgy content, and to plough billions of dollars into machine-learning algorithms that get better at blocking bad actors.

Brian Wieser of Pivotal Research in New York said this was just the beginning. "Facebook seems to not be fully aware of its situation," he said. "They seem to think that 30,000 mostly outsourced contractors working on platform safety is sufficient. Try 10 times that." To wit: in Brazil, far-right politician Jair Bolsonaro fought and won the presidency on WhatsApp. Researchers found that of the top 50 political images circulating on the messaging service before the October ballot, only four were genuine; the others were hoaxes or fake news.

Eight years ago, Facebook reached an agreement known as a consent decree with Washington to settle charges that it had "deceived consumers by failing to keep its privacy promises". Countless security failures later, it has not been hit with a single fine by US authorities. The FTC, however, is reportedly close to levying the $22m fine over failures to live up to that agreement.

The Electronic Privacy Information Centre and others wrote an open letter last week arguing the fine should be $2bn - "well within the agency's scope . . . for violation of a consent decree". It also called for a break-up of Facebook, claiming it reneged on a commitment when it bought WhatsApp not to undermine the company's strict data privacy policy. Brussels fined Facebook (EURO)110m (then £94m) in 2017 over claims about the sanctity of WhatsApp user data.

America is not the only country that could follow Europe by rolling out stringent privacy rules. Brazil and India, big markets for Facebook, are considering data regulation that, whether it takes the form of higher opt-in consents or harsh penalties for security breaches, will make it harder and more expensive to operate.

This is the core of Wieser's argument: Facebook isn't going away but its giant 40% profit margins will fade. The $19bn it spends annually on operations will pale beside what it will need to spend to stay on the right side of the law. "They might think that building a $19bn nuclear warhead is enough to take on the governments of the world, but they're gonna find it's not enough," Wieser warned.

Facebook may well enter a fallow era, as Microsoft did in the 1990s. Venture capitalist Benedict Evans of Andreessen Horowitz said on The Sunday Times's Danny in the Valley podcast: "Big tech companies don't tend to remain dominant very long. IBM is still a big company [but] no one is scared of IBM any more. Microsoft is still a great company, but it does not control the agenda in the tech industry. No one is scared of Microsoft, and that happened quite quickly."

Overlying all this is the law of large numbers. Facebook's share of the digital advertising market will have grown to 21% last year, eMarketer estimates, second only to Google's 31%. Wieser says that investors underestimate the limits of digital advertising's potential to grow.

Zuckerberg's trump card is Instagram. Even if LOL fails and Facebook keeps haemorrhaging young users, Instagram is picking them up. It may not save Facebook, but it will at least extend its reign.

The picture-sharing app has become Facebook's most vital source of growth. An estimated 1bn people use it, up 13% on the year. Zuckerberg has flooded Instagram with ads - and so far it is working: eMarketer forecasts that Instagram will bring in $14bn in ad revenue this year.

Yet as it grows, so too will the consequences and visibility of its failures. The father of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life in 2017, told The Sunday Times this weekend of his conviction that self-harm videos circulating on Instagram helped lead to her suicide.

Zuckerberg tried to debunk assumptions about Facebook in a 1,100-word essay last week in The Wall Street Journal - explaining that he does not sell users' data and is trying hard to fix Facebook's problems. "The only reason bad content remains," he wrote, "is because the people and artificial intelligence systems we use to review it are not perfect - not because we have an incentive to ignore it. Our systems are still evolving and improving."

As with LOL, it is unclear whether anyone out there is willing to listen.

Zuckerberg's annus horribilis January 11, 2018

After heavy criticism of its role in spreading disinformation, Facebook changes its algorithm, deprioritising news stories and viral videos in favour of posts from friends and families.

January 25

Hedge fund guru George Soros labels Facebook a "menace" to society, prompting operations chief Sheryl Sandberg to open a secret investigation into the tycoon.

March 17

The Cambridge Analytica scandal breaks, in which the personal data of tens of millions of people was harvested and then used to send targeted political ads.

April 10

Zuckerberg testifies before Congress, robotically answering questions but largely escaping unscathed. Regarding Russian election meddling via Facebook, he says: "I'm sorry. I started Facebook, I run it, and I'm responsible for what happens here."

April 26

Facebook technology head Mike Schroepfer testifies in parliament over the Cambridge Analytica scandal. A Conservative MP calls the company "a morality-free zone, destructive to a fundamental right to privacy".

May 2

Cambridge Analytica shuts down.

May 22

Zuckerberg testifies behind closed doors in Brussels in front of European politicians.

July 26

Shares plummet in the biggest single-day collapse after Facebook issues a profit warning and warns of slowing growth in Europe and America.

August 27

A UN report calls Facebook a "useful instrument for those seeking to spread hate" in relation to genocide of Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar.

September 24

Instagram founders Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger leave Facebook, following WhatsApp founder Jan Koum, who left in April.

September 28

Facebook announces that a security flaw left as many as 50m accounts exposed to hackers. It later revises the figure to 30m. The FBI opens an investigation.

October 8

Facebook follows a year of security breaches by launching Portal, a video chat screen for the home.

November 14

A New York Times investigation highlights the company's slow response to Russian election interference and its aggressive tactics that included attacking critics.

December 5

Parliament releases a cache of internal Facebook emails from a plaintiff suing in California, providing an alarming look at how the company treats users' data.

December 19

Washington files a lawsuit against Facebook for its role in the Cambridge Analytica affair.

January 18, 2019

The Federal Trade Commission reportedly nears a $22m fine for potential privacy rule violations.

By any measure, they will be fantastic. Consensus net income for 2018 is $21.6bn, a 36% increase on the year, with sales also up 36% to $55bn.

The investment bank JP Morgan said that, far from stumbling, Facebook had reached "rarefied air" and is "still early in the development of its ad platform".

Sheer scale is Facebook's saving grace.

Between Facebook, WhatsApp and Instagram, the company's products are used by 2.6bn people - a third of the planet. The precision with which advertisers can target audiences creates a powerful combination that won't easily be overturned. Last week it emerged Zuckerberg is working on plans to merge Instagram, Facebook Messenger and WhatsApp into a single messaging colossus. The front end of the apps - the interfaces used by consumers - would not change. Yet integrating the underlying infrastructure could offer a powerful new way for brands to reach people. The move could also raise competition concerns.

Yet other factors will slow Facebook down. The biggest is security. Last year's events showed its privacy and safety controls are woeful. Zuckerberg has pledged to hire 30,000 staff to filter out abusive and dodgy content, and to plough billions into machine-learning algorithms that get better at blocking bad actors.

Brian Wieser of Pivotal Research in New York said this was just the beginning.

"Facebook seems to not be fully aware of its situation," he said. "They seem to think that 30,000 mostly outsourced contractors working on platform safety is sufficient. Try 10 times that." To wit: in Brazil, the far-right Jair Bolsonaro fought and won the presidency on WhatsApp. Of the top 50 political images circulating on the messaging service before the October ballot, research found just four were genuine; the rest were hoaxes or fake news. Eight years ago, Facebook reached an agreement known as a consent decree with Washington to settle charges that it had "deceived consumers by failing to keep its privacy promises". Countless security failures later, it has not been hit with a single fine by US authorities. The FTC, however, is reportedly close to levying the $22m fine over failures to live up to that agreement.

The Electronic Privacy Information Centre and others wrote an open letter last week arguing the fine should be $2bn - "well within the agency's scope … for violation of a consent decree". It also called for a break-up of Facebook, claiming it reneged on a commitment when it bought WhatsApp not to undermine the company's strict data privacy policy. Brussels fined Facebook (EURO)110m (then £94m) in 2017 over claims about the sanctity of WhatsApp user data.

America is not the only country that could follow Europe by rolling out stringent privacy rules. Brazil and India, big markets for Facebook, are considering data regulation that, whether it takes the form of higher opt-in consents or harsh penalties for security breaches, will make it harder and more expensive to operate.

This is the core of Wieser's argument: Facebook isn't going away but its giant 40% profit margins will fade. The $19bn it spends annually on operations will pale beside what it will need to spend to stay on the right side of the law. "They might think that building a $19bn nuclear warhead is enough to take on the governments of the world, but they're gonna find it's not enough," Wieser warned.

Facebook may well enter a fallow era, as Microsoft did in the 1990s. Venture capitalist Benedict Evans of Andreessen Horowitz said on The Sunday Times's Danny in the Valley podcast: "Big tech companies don't tend to remain dominant very long. IBM is still a big company [but] no one is scared of IBM any more. Microsoft is still a great company, but it does not control the agenda in the tech www.industry.No one is scared of Microsoft, and that happened quite quickly."

Overlying all this is the law of large numbers. Facebook's share of the digital advertising market will have grown to 21% last year, eMarketer estimates, second only to Google's 31%. Wieser says that investors underestimate the limits of digital advertising's potential to grow.

Zuckerberg's trump card is Instagram.

Even if LOL fails and Facebook keeps haemorrhaging young users, Instagram is picking them up. It may not save Facebook, but it will at least extend its reign. The picture-sharing app has become Facebook's most vital source of growth. An estimated 1bn people use it, up 13% on the year. Zuckerberg has flooded Instagram with ads - and so far it is working: eMarketer forecasts that Instagram will bring in $14bn in ad revenue this year.

Yet as it grows, so too will the impact of its failures. The father of 14-year-old Molly Russell, who took her own life in 2017, told The Sunday Times this weekend he is convinced self-harm videos on Instagram helped lead to her suicide.

Zuckerberg tried to debunk assumptions about Facebook in an essay last week in The Wall Street Journal - explaining that he does not sell users' data and is trying hard to fix Facebook's problems. "The only reason bad content remains," he wrote, "is because the people and artificial intelligence systems we use to review it are not perfect - not because we have an incentive to ignore it. Our systems are still evolving and improving." As with LOL, it is unclear whether anyone out there is willing to listen.

urn:contentItem:5VPH-KDB1-F0J6-J3T8-00000-00Facebook took an hour to respond as video spread;social media2019-03-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 13Facebook took an hour to respond as video spreadsocial mediaJohn McDuling

Facebook took at least an hour to remove the live stream footage of the horrific Christchurch terrorist attack.

The social media giant and New Zealand police revealed fresh details about last week's massacre, which prompted Prime Minister Scott Morrison and his counterpart across the Tasman Jacinda Ardern to call for co-ordinated action against big tech companies.

The hour that elapsed between the start of the live stream and the video being taken down would prove to be a crucial delay that enabled the video to spread uncontrollably across the web.

In an update on Thursday, Facebook said it believed there was coordination by "bad actors" to distribute the videos through as many channels online as possible. It revealed 300,000 versions of the video made it past the artificial intelligence controls designed to prevent illicit content such as pornography and extremist content such as terrorist propaganda, from making it on to the platform.

Artificial intelligence experts cast doubt over Facebook's ability to use technology to prevent live streaming of terror attacks from happening again.

"We know that artificial intelligence is not capable of the subtlety of reasoning or the depth of understanding required to filter content in a fail-safe way," Toby Walsh, a professor in artificial intelligence at the University of NSW said.

The Christchurch attack - and Facebook and Google's role in it - has occurred in the middle of an increasingly heated global conversation over how to regulate the two digital giants.

urn:contentItem:5WN4-JPV1-JCBW-N0V3-00000-00Facebook to pay $5bn in privacy deal;Prosecution threat to Zuckerberg in settlement ; Facebook to pay $5bn in US over privacy breaches2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 37,40Facebook to pay $5bn in privacy dealProsecution threat to Zuckerberg in settlement ; Facebook to pay $5bn in US over privacy breachesJames Dean

Mark Zuckerberg faces prosecution if he misleads regulators about how well Facebook is protecting user privacy under the terms of a record $5 billion settlement with America's consumer watchdog.

The chief executive of the technology company and publisher must submit quarterly and annual reports to the Federal Trade Commission stating whether or not Facebook is complying with a new programme designed to safeguard its users. False certifications will lead to criminal and civil penalties, the commission said.

As well as the certifications, the commission ordered Facebook's board to create an independent privacy committee and nominate specialist compliance officers to end Mr Zuckerberg's "unfettered control" over user privacy. The US is increasing scrutiny of its largest technology companies. On Tuesday, the Department of Justice announced a wide-ranging competition investigation into the dominance of Big Tech. The justice department and the commission are conducting separate investigations into Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Alphabet, the owner of Google.

Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said yesterday that Amazon had "destroyed the retail industry" across the US and there was "no question" that the company had hurt competition. Apple shares lost 0.01 per cent and Alphabet shed 0.7 per cent.

Facebook, one of the world's largest internet companies, owns the social network of the same name, WhatsApp and Facebook Messenger messaging services and Instagram, the picture and video-sharing network. Facebook, valued at $575 billion, makes most of its money from digital advertising.

The commission's $5 billion penalty is by far the largest imposed on a company for consumer privacy violations. Facebook said in April that it expected to pay between $3 billion and $5 billion to settle the investigation and took a $3 billion first-quarter charge to cover the expected costs.

In its second-quarter report, published last night, Facebook booked a further $2 billion charge to cover the commission's fine and an unrelated $1.1 billion tax expense. Profit fell to $2.6 billion from $5.1 billion a year before as revenue climbed to $16.9 billion from $13.2 billion. The figures beat analysts' forecasts and Facebook shares were up by 3.5 per cent in after-hours trading, having closed at $204.66, up by 1.1 per cent, or $2.30, for the day.

The overhaul at Facebook marks the culmination of a long-running investigation by the commission into the company's protections for user privacy. It was triggered by the Cambridge Analytica scandal last year, when a whistleblower revealed that the nowdefunct British political consultancy used 87 million profiles harvested from Facebook without its users' consent to target voters with political adverts.

The commission alleges that Facebook "repeatedly used deceptive disclosures and settings" to undermine user privacy, violating an order the commission imposed in 2012. Many users were unaware that Facebook was sharing Continued on page 40, col 4 Continued from page 37 their personal information with third parties, including Cambridge Analytica, the commission said.

The FTC's commissioners voted by three to two to approve the settlement. The two dissenting commissioners said yesterday that it did not go far enough.

One, Rohit Chopra, said: "Facebook's flagrant violations were a direct result of their business model of mass surveillance and manipulation, and this action blesses this model." Mr Chopra said that a grant of immunity to Facebook's officers and directors was "a giveaway" because they were legally bound to ensure compliance with the 2012 order. The other commissioner, Rebecca Slaughter, said: "We should have initiated litigation against Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg."

Ms Slaughter said that the $5 billion fine was "insufficient" and that she was sceptical that the settlement "will have a meaningful disciplining effect on how Facebook treats data and privacy".

The three other commissioners said: "The relief we have achieved today solves concrete problems, rather than venting frustration with individuals."

As well as the certifications, the commission ordered Facebook's board to create an independent privacy committee and nominate specialist compliance officers to end Mr Zuckerberg's "unfettered control" over user privacy.

The US is increasing scrutiny of its largest technology companies. On Tuesday, the Department of Justice announced a wide-ranging competition investigation into the dominance of Big Tech. The justice department and the commission are conducting separate investigations into Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Alphabet, the owner of Google. Facebook confirmed last night that it is subject to a competition investigation by the FTC.

Steven Mnuchin, the Treasury secretary, said yesterday that Amazon had "destroyed the retail industry" across the US and there was "no question" that the company had hurt competition. Apple shares lost 0.01 per cent and Alphabet shed 0.7 per cent.

Facebook, one of the world's largest internet companies, owns the social network of the same name, WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger and Instagram. Facebook, valued at $575 billion, makes most of its money from advertising.

The commission's $5 billion penalty is by far the largest imposed on a company for consumer privacy violations. Facebook said in April that it expected to pay between $3 billion and $5 billion to settle the investigation and took a $3 billion first-quarter charge to cover the expected costs.

In its second-quarter report, published last night, Facebook booked a further $2 billion charge to cover the commission's fine and an unrelated $1.1 billion tax expense. Profit fell to $2.6 billion from $5.1 billion a year before as revenue climbed to $16.9 billion from $13.2 billion. The figures beat analysts' forecasts and Facebook shares were up by 3.5 per cent in after-hours trading, having closed at $204.66, up by 1.1 per cent, or $2.30, for the day.

The overhaul at Facebook marks the culmination of a long-running investigation by the commission into the company's protections for user privacy.

It was triggered by the Cambridge Analytica scandal last year, when a whistleblower revealed that the now-defunct British political consultancy used 87 million profiles harvested from Facebook without its users' consent to target voters with political adverts.

The commission alleges that Facebook "repeatedly used deceptive disclosures and settings" to undermine user privacy, violating an order the commission imposed in 2012. Many users were unaware that Facebook was sharing their personal information with third parties, including Cambridge Analytica, the commission said.

The FTC's commissioners voted by three to two to approve the settlement. The two dissenting commissioners said yesterday that it did not go far enough.

One, Rohit Chopra, said: "Facebook's flagrant violations were a direct result of their business model of mass surveillance and manipulation, and this action blesses this model." Mr Chopra said that a grant of immunity to Facebook's officers and directors was "a giveaway" because they were legally bound to ensure compliance with the 2012 order.

The other commissioner, Rebecca Slaughter, said: "We should have initiated litigation against Facebook and Mark Zuckerberg."

Ms Slaughter said that the $5 billion fine was "insufficient" and that she was sceptical that the settlement "will have a meaningful disciplining effect on how Facebook treats data and privacy".

The three other commissioners said: "The relief we have achieved today solves concrete problems, rather than venting frustration with individuals."

Facebook has agreed to pay more than $5bn to settle its cases with US regulators over misusing user data, in two settlements that it hopes will help alleviate some of the political hostility it has faced since the  Cambridge Analytica scandal.

The Federal Trade Commission  announced on Wednesday it had agreed a settlement with the social media company, which marked the largest civil penalty the commission has ever handed out.

Facebook has also agreed to impose new privacy protections as part of the agreement, including setting up a privacy committee, which will be independent from the board, and to appoint individual privacy compliance officers.

Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive, and the privacy officers will be required to certify that the company is in compliance with Facebook’s privacy programme on a quarterly basis. “Any false certification will subject them to individual civil and criminal penalties,” the FTC said.

Separately, the company has also agreed to pay $100m to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which said Facebook had made misleading disclosures over the misuse of user data.

The cases were both launched in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica data scandal in which user data were leaked to a political research group through a third-party app. 

Since the scandal, Facebook has faced a barrage of criticism from regulators and politicians in Europe and the US, which have accused the company not only of misusing user data but also allowing its platforms to be used to spread disinformation.

Facebook’s shares were down 0.6 per cent in morning, trading at $201, suggesting the settlement was broadly as investors had expected.

An ‘unprecedented’ penalty

Joe Simons, the chair of the FTC, said of the Facebook settlement: “The magnitude of the $5bn penalty and sweeping conduct relief are unprecedented in the history of the FTC. The relief is designed not only to punish future violations but, more importantly, to change Facebook’s entire privacy culture to decrease the likelihood of continued violations.”

The decision has split the FTC internally however, with the two Democratic commissioners voting against the settlement for not going far enough.

In a  dissenting statement, Rohit Chopra, one of the Democratic commissioners, said: “The proposed settlement does little to change the business model or practices that led to the recidivism. 

“The settlement imposes no meaningful changes to the company’s structure or financial incentives, which led to these violations. Nor does it include any restrictions on the company’s mass surveillance or advertising tactics.”

Six key terms of Facebook’s deal with the FTC

- Facebook must launch an independent privacy committee, which the FTC says will remove the “unfettered control” of chief Mark Zuckerberg over privacy-related decisions.

- The company must create a team of privacy compliance officers, who must, with Zuckerberg, certify that the company is in compliance with Facebook’s privacy programme on a quarterly basis to the commission. “Any false certification will subject them to individual civil and criminal penalties,” the FTC said.

- Facebook must document incidents when data of 500 or more users has been compromised and notify the commission within 30 days.

- The company must “exercise greater oversight” over third-party apps, and cut off app developers that fail to certify that they are in compliance with its policies or justify why they need certain data.

- Facebook must make clear to users its use of facial recognition technology and gain consent from them if it changes the way it uses this technology.

- The company must introduce a “comprehensive data security program”, encrypt users’ passwords and regularly check they are stored in this way.

As part of the agreement, Facebook will have to report to the FTC within 30 days if there has been any data breach that affects 500 or more users.

The order also “resolves all consumer-protection claims known by the FTC prior to June 12, 2019”. This means that recent potential data breaches, such as revelations earlier this year that Facebook improperly stored hundreds of millions of its users’ passwords internally in a readable format, will not be pursued.

It does not impose any restrictions on how much data the company can collect, or how it uses it to target advertising at certain groups. Mr Chopra said: “The order allows Facebook to decide for itself how much information it can harvest from users and what it can do with that information, as long as it creates a paper trail.”

Christine Wilson, one of the FTC’s Republican commissioners, said: “We do not have the legal authority to remove Mr Zuckerberg from the driver’s seat, but we have imposed a robust system of checks and balances that extinguishes his ability unilaterally to chart the path for consumer privacy at Facebook.”

A ‘sharper turn’ towards privacy

Colin Stretch, Facebook’s general counsel, said  in a blog post that the agreement “will mark a sharper turn toward privacy, on a different scale than anything we’ve done in the past”.

In a separate post, Facebook said on Wednesday that it had  cut off access to users’ friend data by Microsoft and Sony. Late last year the company ended a dozen data-sharing agreements with big tech companies following concern that users were unclear how their data were being used and shared. However, Microsoft and Sony had continued to access some friend data by “mistake”, Facebook said. 

The FTC accused Facebook of three separate violations of a previous agreement with the regulator. First, it said that the company incorrectly told consumers that they could limit the sharing of their information to certain groups, whereas it was sharing that information more broadly, with third party app developers.

Second, Facebook did not adequately assess and address privacy risks posed by third party app developers.

Third, Facebook told some users they would have to turn on facial recognition technology, even though it was already on by default.

The FTC also announced on Wednesday that it had filed a complaint against Cambridge Analytica for “deceptive acts and practices to harvest personal information from Facebook users for political and commercial targeted advertising purposes”. 

The company, which has now gone bankrupt, has not settled the allegations, the FTC said. However, the FTC settled individual charges with Alexander Nix, Cambridge Analytica’s chief executive, and app developer and academic Aleksandr Kogan, which will now require them to be more transparent about how and why they handle personal information, and to delete any personal data they collected during the scandal.

urn:contentItem:5WK1-TP31-JCDG-R003-00000-00Facebook to pay FTC $5bn fine over Cambridge Analytica2019-07-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:35ZLexisNexisFacebook to pay FTC $5bn fine over Cambridge AnalyticaDev Kundaliya

$5 billion Facebook fine would be the largest ever penalty imposed by the FTC

The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has approved a $5 billion settlement with Facebook over the sharing of data with political consultancy Cambridge Analytica.

The FTC opened its investigation in March last year following claims that data from approximately 87 million Facebook users had been acquired by Cambridge Analytica. The FTC's probe has largely focused on whether the sharing of users' data violated a 2011 agreement between the regulator and the company.

The penalty will mark the largest in the FTC's history by a large margin, according to Reuters, if agreed by the civil division of the US Department of Justice. It would also set a new bar for privacy enforcement by US regulators, who have hitherto only brought a handful of cases against big tech firms.

In March 2018, several news outlets reported that Cambridge Analytica had collected the data of millions of Facebook users.

The company had purchased the data from an academic who had created a quiz app that was also able to collect personal information, not only from consenting users, but also their Facebook friends, without their knowledge.

The access to data in this was only cut in 2015 after Facebook belatedly amended this feature.

However, the FTC believes that this contravened a 2011 agreement whereby Facebook had promised not to share users' data with third parties without their knowledge and consent. This had followed earlier data sharing scandals at Facebook.

According to some reports, the FTC agreed several months ago to impose a sizable fine against Facebook, but the members of the commission had divided opinions about the scope and size of the punishment. One of the contentious issues to address was whether Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg should be held liable for the alleged violation of the 2011 agreement.

Last week, US President Donald Trump accused Facebook and several other social media companies of being unfair and biased against conservatives. He also criticised Facebook's Libra cryptocurrency project.

For man, though, the $5 billion fine is still too small for a company the size of Facebook. "This reported $5 billion penalty is barely a tap on the wrist, not even a slap," said Senator Richard Blumenthal, a Connecticut Democrat, according to Bloomberg.

"Such a financial punishment for purposeful, blatant illegality is chump change for a company that makes tens of billions of dollars every year," he added.

Marc Rotenberg, president of the Electronic Privacy Information Centre (EPIC), commented: "Something clearly has to be done to strengthen the data protection practices of that company."

Rotenberg's complaint against Facebook had led to FTC's 2011 deal with Facebook, addressing several deceiving practices of the social media company.

urn:contentItem:5WXT-N3M1-DXVP-V2HF-00000-00‘Facebook-topia’: Why we may soon live on corporate island-nations2019-08-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:35ZLexisNexisTRAVEL‘Facebook-topia’: Why we may soon live on corporate island-nationsGregory Thomas

At a time when the Amazon rainforest is burning out of control, political polarization in the U.S. feels irreparable, technological development seems to be increasing exponentially, and climate change looms as an existential threat to our species, it's hard not to speculate about humanity soon undergoing some massive changes. Maybe it's a zombie apocalypse, maybe techno-utopia. Who's to say?

Patri Friedman has an idea. He's been working on a radical vision of the future of human civilization the better part of two decades. The self-described anarcho-capitalist, who lives in the mountains above Los Gatos, believes some of us may soon find ourselves living on permanent offshore island-nations — perhaps ones financed by big tech's FAANG companies.

"I definitely see that at some point we'll get corporate states, and I know some people find that creepy," Friedman says. "I'm kind of on the fence about whether I'd like living in Apple-topia or Google-topia — definitely not Facebook-topia or Netflix-topia."

As Friedman sees it, "sovereignty is fragmenting in the 21st century." Countries around the world — either weary or intrepid — are beginning to think about ways to create new jurisdictions for the express purpose of tinkering with rules and regulations. Sometimes as a way to dodge rising sea levels, other times as a means of sparking economic opportunities.

Friedman's interest is in experimenting with new governing structures via seasteading. Built on the premise of constructing autonomous offshore territories in the ocean, the concept allows for the formation of new communities that craft their own governing charters. Prospective citizens would be able to opt in to whichever island-state they may prefer.

Though not yet in practice, seasteading is gaining interest in pockets across the globe, Friedman says. To pursue this idea, the former Google engineer founded the Seasteading Institute in San Francisco in 2008 with $500,000 of funding from PayPal founder Peter Thiel. The institute is a nonprofit that consults with groups and countries around the world on proposals to design special zones for experimenting with new forms of government.

To test his seasteading hypothesis, in 2009, Friedman founded an event called Ephemerisle. The annual floating festival of boats and barges draws hundreds of people each summer to a remote estuary in the Sacramento-San Joaquin River Delta. They hang out, party and dabble in small-scale world-building. Over the years, it has drawn tech luminaries including Thiel and Google co-founder Sergey Brin.

Today, Friedman sits on the board of the Seasteading Institute and consults on seasteading pilot projects wherever they may emerge. We're not long from a time when countries jump into this idea with both feet, he says.

"What we're seeing today, in 2019, is we're well into the 21st century and countries are realizing that they need to do these kinds of innovations and experiments to succeed," Friedman says. "So that growing interest from countries is why I quit my job at Google and I'm working full-time with these projects."

I called Friedman on the phone recently to discuss the development of seasteading, his current work and the evolution of Ephemerisle. The interview is transcribed below, edited for length and clarity. For the full conversation, listen to the Wild West podcast.

San Francisco Chronicle: I know you're working on some top secret projects at the moment that you can't discuss in detail, but can you give me the broad strokes?

Friedman: What I'm working on now is the idea of working with governments to designate an area of the ocean or an area of the land to have somewhat different laws from the rest of the country. And then a group of people — a community or company — would create a floating or land-based real estate development there that people would move into if they wanted to have those better laws. So I'm consulting with groups around the world doing this.

What is the benefit to a government of creating a new zone where people would live outside of that government's control? How does that relationship work?

You can look at China's special economic zones as an example, or at Dubai. The reason they do it is because, well, to the programmer, this seems perfectly natural to me. When I was at Google, if you were going to roll out a change to Google's web server, you wouldn't roll it out for everyone at once. You'd test it out and then maybe put it online for one out of a million users and then eventually one out of a thousand users and you'd slowly scale it up and test it.

It's the same thing with laws. Maybe a country wants to try out, as China did, more free-market systems without changing the entire country.

Another reason is corruption. It's just really hard to root out the culture of corruption. If you start with empty land and have a different group of people — say, a new company — create the laws and courts and police, the idea is you can create a bubble of honest courts and non-corrupt officials even in a corrupt country. It might be easier to reform the country by creating these bubbles — by moving parts of the country into them rather than trying to change the entire culture of the country.

That touches on the appeal of seasteading. It's the utopian idea that we can do society better if we just had a clean slate to start over. Why should we believe we can do it better than we do it now?

I think some amount of skepticism is great and that it really depends what the stated goal is. I'm very confident that we can make laws and governments that work better. But at the same time I would say that those laws and governments would have many of the same problems that they do today.

As a programmer, we know that periodically… you can improve things. Furthermore, you can improve things a lot more if, every now and then, you start from scratch — you do a full rewrite — than you can by just patching existing code that uses existing libraries.

So the idea that if we can copy best-practice legal systems from around the world, and if we can do some clean-slate rewrites that people opt into that are only parts of the laws initially and test them out, we can definitely improve the rate of progress of legal development. But we'll never get away from the fundamental challenges and tradeoffs that happen in any government.

Can you give a quick history of the Seasteading Institute?

It began with my interest in new countries and better systems of government, starting in about the year 2000. Ephermerisle was actually part of the early history because I went to Burning Man and was really impressed at how much energy people put into building their own infrastructure, and at the same time sad that it was all poured into something temporary that was all torn down.

As I was thinking about this question of, how do you start new countries, I tied it together and thought, maybe you can start this festival where people went out to international waters in boats and spent a week actually contractually living under some different legal system.

And then in late 2007 some people who worked for Peter Thiel connected us and he was really excited about the idea and gave me a half million-dollar donation to found the nonprofit, which we did in April of 2008.

Talk about how Ephemerisle got started and how that first year of the festival went.

Ephemerisle is part of the earliest genesis of seasteading, the idea being, how do we make new countries? Well we gotta get people comfortable with trying out new legal systems and maybe it's easier to do that for a week a year than to get them to move there full-time.

I imagined this idea of people gathering together in international waters, forming different islands and signing agreements about what the legal system would be for the week. But the ocean is rough and expensive and...there aren't comfortable international waters nearby like there would be in Florida, say. So we said, well let's start out someplace nearby that's much easier but that's connected to the ocean.

We picked the Sacramento delta. This is a region of the Bay Area which a lot of people don't know about. It's almost like a Louisiana bayou of the bay. We said, alright we're going to go out there and make an island. We hired someone named Chicken John, an early Burner who'd done art raft projects, and we rented out all the houseboats from nearby Paradise Point Marina and spent days hammering and drilling and putting things together — art projects and platforms.

We were not able to anchor the platforms and the boats out in the open water. We ended up having to attach to the shore, which was not ideal. But again the whole idea here is to form a learning arc of progress.

So it was what it was the first year. It was just really incredible. People came from around the world. There were probably 100 to 150 of us to just play with this idea of rules and art on the water. There weren't enough of us for there to be different islands. The focus was much more on just getting floating and being able to eat and sleep, rather than new laws. But everyone kind of came together around the idea.

How has the festival evolved over the years?

There's kind of two axes of evolution, one of which has worked really well and one of which hasn't gone at all.

The (first of the) two axes is the idea of having different rules and culture on different islands — that anybody can start their own island and choose who joins them and that we have a real diversity. That's gone really well. There's a main island, Elysium, which is quite large and has a bunch of rules, and there's also many, many small islands.

The other axis is the movement towards this vision of truly testing out new laws for the week as far from the current legal environment as it's possible to get in this world, on the high seas. Part of the idea of the Sacramento delta is it's physically connected to the ocean. We thought, we'll learn to meet the challenges of boating on the delta then we'll move maybe to the Sacramento River, then we'll move into the bay...and then maybe we'll move just offshore — maybe just outside Half Moon Bay or outside the Golden Gate Bridge. Then we'll find a reef or other protected place in international waters and hold the true high seas Ephemerisle there.

On that axis, well, I think people have been great at accumulating ships and platforms and experience (but) the festival has not moved in ten years from that initial location. So it's not showing any signs of progressing towards greater legal autonomy.

When I visited Ephemerisle this summer, one thing I noticed was the constant process of people negotiating and compromising with one another. You told me, "Rules are to Ephemerisle as art is to Burning Man." What did you mean by that?

That negotiation and compromise and constant discussion of what the rules should be and then most importantly that there are different rules in different places — that's absolutely critical to the entire philosophy of competitive governments. That is the seasteading nature. And to the degree that that's happening at Ephemerisle, it is realizing the vision. I think that's super exciting.

What I mean by rules are to Ephemerisle as art is to Burning Man is that Ephemerisle is not just Burning Man on the water. It's about playing with rules and culture and having multiple sets of rules that are hopefully very different in close proximity, and having the experiences of helping create rule systems and experience different rule systems and move during the week to these little floating villages that are very different. The whole idea of seasteading is that we need more diversity and experimentation with rules.

I personally come from the political philosophy of anarcho-capitalism, which my dad helped to create. People sometimes say, "Oh, you're an anarchist. That must mean that you want no rules or no cops." In truth, it's just the opposite. We think that rules are so important that, rather than just having one set of rules that everyone lives under, we think it's critical to have a bunch of different sets of rules with different pros and cons that nurture different virtues.

To me, hell is one-world government. No matter what the laws are — even if it had whatever the closest to what everyone in the world would together choose — to me, that's hell because it's vulnerable. If everyone does things the same way then one mistake, one weakness, and everybody loses. What's most important to me is seeing a lot of different regions that are truly different. That's the spirit of Ephemerisle.

What are some of the rules that you have lived by that you would like to change?

It's hard to briefly answer that question because I feel like the rule set of the United States of America is so far from my ideal that I don't want to pick out just one thing.

This is something where, often with seasteading, I try to keep things on the meta level. We don't endorse a particular political system or particular set of rules because doing so can distract people from the big idea. And the big idea is not, here's a utopia or here's one set of rules that we think everybody should follow. The entire idea is we need to play with rules more. Rules should be an art — part of the critical infrastructure of our world.

It's like code. You can copy and remix laws and bring them from place to place in a way that you can't easily do with buildings and cities and highways. But yet we don't. We just use our locally evolved rules and we have terrible decision-making mechanisms — like democracy in America, where the government every couple of years collects a few dozen bits of information from me about my preferences. It's terrible. We now have half a century worth of Nobel Prize-winning economists on how democracy tends to produce laws that favor special interests over the masses, even though that's kind of the opposite of its founding philosophy.

I think the meta rules are so bad…that I feel like much of the content of the laws is bad. Although I will give a shout-out to British common law and say that, inside those hundreds of thousands of pages of regulations, these general ideas of courts and contracts and those precedents I think are quite good.

Let's say that a new seasteading island is getting underway. Who is tasked with coming up with the new rules?

There's the democratic analogy, which is the community of initial citizens comes together and uses some collaborative decision-making process to create the initial rules.

Then there's the sort of start-up model, which is that a small group of founders comes together and their governance is sort of like the prototype or the mission statement or initial product for a company — that's what they're going to build it around.

And then there's the special economic zone model where you have a developer who's going to hand things off to an operator — they're going to create this real estate project… So there, it's a process of the developer trying to make money and negotiation with the government and with the anchor tenants.

Do you view this as a scalable alternative to the system of sovereign nations that we have right now?

As I see it, sovereignty is fragmenting in the 21st century and becoming commoditized. Just look at the large internet companies, for example. They have significant power over information that would traditionally have been held by the sovereign, just from technological changes.

I do see this as making the system more flexible instead of dividing everything up geographically into 150 units that have these rigid bodies of law that don't learn enough from each other and don't experiment. I just want to see a world that's more like software, where people are regularly trying changes and rewrites and copying new things and using new language and new modules. But then for safety they're trying them out at a small scale — letting people use them voluntarily and only scaling them up as they prove safe. I think it's absolutely sustainable and scalable.

So what you're saying is, if in five or six years we see a press release announcing that Mark Zuckerberg has launched a big platform off the Pacific coast as a private retreat center for Facebook's largest shareholders, we shouldn't be surprised.

I definitely think that large corporations actually operating these is in the future. … I definitely see that at some point we'll get corporate states, and I know some people find that creepy. I'm kind of on the fence about whether I'd like living in Apple-topia or Google-topia — definitely not Facebook-topia or Netflix-topia.

But the idea is that these are alternatives that you go to if you want, and if you don't like it, don't go there. It's really core to our philosophy that these things be opt-in. It's wrong to change people's government out from under them. But it's also really bad if there aren't new governments that you can choose to go to.

CORRECTION: An earlier version of this article misstated Friedman's political philosophy. The Chronicle regrets the error.
