Paul Ryan Denies Resignation Report; DOJ and AT&T Face OffLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Welcome back, Trish.

TRISH REGAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Thanks, Neil. Good to be back. Anyway, we've got a brief jumping session right now all over the place.

Breaking news, everyone, we've got Dow that's swinging back and forth, in and out in negative territory. It was up quite a bit earlier in the session, more than 200 now. Down to the flat line and now back up 50.

Investors are continuing to weigh basically the impact of the Trump administration's aggressive approach to China. They're not sure how it's all been to turn out. We're going to dive in to that over the next hour. So you can think about how you should be interpreting this news and what is going to mean for the market.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. It is great to be back all the way from Hawaii. I'll have a little more on that at the end of the show.

But meanwhile, let's talk about this trade war that everybody is so fearful about. I'll tell you, they're starting to basically come to grips with it. You've got fears are starting to ease. You're starting to see that the U.S. and China begin negotiations to address the tensions that had rocked global markets in recent weeks.

Investors are still trying to digest of the news at last to record sell- off, which is followed by a sharp rebound, nice to see yesterday. And we're going to be watching here all this drama that's unfolding right up until the closing bell. But I will ask yet again, are these markets overreacting? I think so. We've got some intel.

Plus, Facebook woes continue to pile on as U.S. officials say they are investigating the social network over its controversial privacy policies. And Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg out there finally feeling a little bit of heat. Now reports say he will testify before Congress. Is this beginning or the end for this company, for the Facebook founder? We have more coming up.

But first, back to our top story, this trade dispute with China. Will investors give President Trump a fair deal in terms of these markets? Will China give him a fair deal in terms of trade?

Joining me right now, Hudson Institute Senior Fellow, Michael Pillsbury, along with our very own Charles Payne. It's good to see you both.

Michael, I'll start with you. You know, look, people say the Trump administration is anti-free trade. It seems like kind of a drastic, drastic criticism, especially, I think, if you allow China to continue on the path it is you're going to wake up a decade from now, we're going to be the next France. They're going to be the hegemonic power in the world taking the place of the USA. So, with that in mind, what needs to happen so that things start to shake out in a more fair way?

MICHAEL PILLSBURY, SENIOR FELLOW, HUDSON INSTITUTE: Well, the first thing is China has got to take President Trump seriously, and they've done that. I think they've made some fairly major concessions in the last few days. That's probably why the market is calming down.

President Trump did not really declare a trade war at all. He had very, very limited measures, measures that were talked about for many years. The only thing is he's actually doing it, instead of just talking about it. But I don't see a really harsh pushback from the Chinese.

Their turnoffs against the steel and aluminum tariffs were very small, $3 billion to match $3 billion. They haven't only replied to this yet. But they have certainly offered to negotiate, and so some very conciliatory things almost an apology, Trish, where they say, "We were willing to open up our market, we're willing to open up some more sectors to foreign investment." So, I think, as you say, it's been really exaggerated.

And President Trump, he's probably showing that he's a master negotiator here. He's preserving his ties with China, which he needs for North Korea and getting their attention to start these negotiations. So, overall, I think, it's a pretty optimistic outcome over the last three or four days. It could have gone much differently.

REGAN: Charles, one of the things that frustrated me about China and has over the last number of years since I've, frankly, been following all of this is that China really does take advantage of us and U.S. companies. And you know what? The CEOs, they don't care because they want access to that Chinese market because it's going to be great for their quarterly results.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Right.

REGAN: And, frankly, President Obama didn't really care so much either because, I think, there's been such a concentration by so many in Washington on the next election, much like CEOs are focused on the next quarter's results that they don't appreciate the context of what's going on here. They don't appreciate how this is all going to affect our population down the road, our kids, Charles, if we allow China to continue stealing our technology and making such onerous demands on our companies.

PAYNE: You know, I agree with you 1000 percent. Now, listen, everyone gives a lip service. You know, there are endless articles where Jack Lew, you know, was livid about the circumstances and he talked about them --

PILLSBURY: That's right.

PAYNE: -- but they never offered solutions. They never had any sort of real threat against China that will make China curb their predatory actions. And let's face it, when China joined the World Trade Organization that was going to make them a legitimate player and follow all the rules. Of course, they didn't follow the rules. And who can blame China? They are.

You started to show up talking about their grand ambitions. They do have grand ambitions. And right now, by 2026, their economy could be bigger than ours.

And, you know, couple India and other Asian nations, and America starts to falls into the sort of zone where Europe is. And Europe can't turn around. They're done unfortunately. And so, if we're going to make a stand, we have to make a stand at this very point.

And, you know, one example I like to use Trish, is a G.M. Buick division has an SUV, the Envision. The Envision is only made in Singapore, right, in Shanghai, rather. And it's exported to this country. It was a big hit last year.

Now, that's great for General Motors and their shareholders. It's great for the American consumers who probably get a pretty good car at a pretty good price. And it's great for the Chinese worker who made it. There's one person missing from the equation and that's the American factory worker, auto worker who might have otherwise had made this product. And that's why there's a different bifurcation.

You know, China hasn't pushed back but Wall Street has pushed back. Last week, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, every day at 2:00, approximately 2:00, a gigantic sell program went off. Ultimately it took 1200 Dow points out of the market. There was no new news at 2:00.

Every single day at that point we saw the markets fell off dramatically. I think Wall Street has been pushing back on this a lot harder than China has.

REGAN: Look, you know, Michael, I get Wall Street, but what I think is a critical here is that we not look at the day-to-day, and I would remind traders not to look at the day-to-day because I'll tell you, 10 years from now you're going to wake up and had a heck of a problem on your hand if you don't deal with the China stuff now. So if we tick a little pain along the way, we will be better off. It is mind-boggling to me.

I mean, they're out creating their version of the WTO. They're investing in many economies in Latin America, in Pakistan, in Iran --

PILLSBURY: Africa.

REGAN: -- or Russia, Africa as well, places that they can seek commodity resources in. I mean, they have a very definite plan to be the world's largest economic power and quite perhaps possibly the world's largest military power. So, if we don't wake up and deal with that at some point, Michael, I think we're going to have much bigger problems on our hands than 600-point drop in the Dow.

PILLSBURY: I agree. I agree with Charles, too. As you know, I wrote a book about this three years ago, which is widely criticized as being alarmist.

And now President Trump has not only accepted some of the premises, he's released a much better report, if I may say so, than my book just last week. It's 250 pages long. Example after example after example of what President Obama used to call the "gangsterization" of our companies. That's why President Trump is moving forward on several fronts. It's not just tariffs. It's this new suit at the WTO in Geneva.

There's number of other measures. And, frankly, there is bipartisan support for what he is doing. Senator Chuck Schumer is often seen as enemy of the President, very quickly endorsed President Trump last Thursday on the tightening up on technology purchases here in the United States.

The bill has attracted the co-sponsorship of Dianne Feinstein who would be happy to call a progressive liberal, I think. So this problem has gone on for so long that just these limited steps seems to be producing a lot of bipartisan support. That's why the day-to-day fluctuation in the market really kind of a shortsighted. And some people who didn't listen are probably losing money now.

REGAN: Yes. Well, they'll make it up. Very quickly, Charles, there are some examples, I think, out there of Chinese companies now looking to invest in the U.S. because, look, we're not going to continue with the current status quo.

PAYNE: Absolutely. Well, you know, two news items today. One is a smaller company, but it's really important, JinkoSolar, the fourth largest solar manufacturer in the world that Chinese company probably will be breaking ground here. It becomes official today in Jacksonville, $50 million project, 400,000 square feet.

Here is the most important thing. This comes after President Trump levied the 30 percent tariff on their product. So now they're going to bring and manufacturing here and of course --

REGAN: They're going to bring it here?

PAYNE: -- we know Foxconn, of course, is building out big time. They made an acquisition today. And while there are pros and cons to it, people need to pay attention.

REGAN: Michael, Charles, good to see you guys.

PAYNE: You got it.

REGAN: Thank you so much. Good perspective. And make sure, everyone, watch Charles on "Making Money" tonight, 6:00 p.m. Eastern right here on Fox Business.

Turning to our other top story, Facebook says it will not confirm reports that CEO, Mark Zuckerberg will testify before Congress about how Facebook collects and stores user data. But Mr. Zuckerberg says he will not appear before the U.K. parliament. All of this as we have uncovered video from eight years ago of Apple co-founder, Steve Jobs, warning Mark Zuckerberg and other tech CEOs about user privacy.

For the latest, let's go right now to Deirdre Bolton who has been following the story from day one. Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Trish, Facebook is under pressure. It is facing investigations from 37 states attorneys general, including tech-heavy states California, Massachusetts, New York. It is also now facing specific lawsuits just this morning from counties, such as IllinoisCook County, that includes Chicago and surrounding areas.

So, basically those areas are just joining this legal fight against Facebook and Cambridge Analytica over the misuse of data scraped from social media profiles claiming that both companies violated state fraud law. So that is the paperwork from Cook County, Illinois. So this lawsuit claims that Cambridge Analytica tricked Facebook users with quizzes and that Facebook knew, this is really serious, Trish, this accusation, and did nothing to stop it.

Now, as you point it out, Steve Jobs, seemed to have a premonition about this relationship between tech and privacy getting more cloudy. Here is what he said eight years ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE JOBS, CO-FOUNDER, APPLE: The Silicon Valley is not monolithic. We've always had a very different view of privacy than some of our colleagues in the Valley. We take privacy extremely seriously. And some people want to share more data than other people do.

Ask them. Ask them every time. Make them tell you to stop asking them, if they get tired of you asking them. Let them know precisely what you're going to do with their data.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: I'm sure Mark Zuckerberg wishes he had seen that or heard that or paid attention because that Cook County lawsuit specifically states "Facebook is not a social media company, it is the largest data mining operation in existence." It further claims that Facebook worked to keep developers on its platform plying them with sensitive data at the expense of its users' privacy.

The Federal Trade Commission also investigating Facebook. It signaled today that its probe of the company is broad. So that's a key word because it's never what a company wants to hear. It implies impending regulation.

Mark Zuckerberg may also testify on Capitol Hill not clear yet. He has been invited to a hearing on April 10th. If he goes, he's going to be asked questions about Facebook's policies regarding protection and monitoring of consumer data.

Senator Grassley is the one who issue the invitation, also extended the same to Google's CEO and Twitter's CEO. But essentially, Trish, this opens up huge questions for big tech, for privacy, for potential regulation. All of these companies right away, they have to spend more money on their legal teams. Probably Mark Zuckerberg has an extra direct report because of this and it is certainly going to be a distraction to the way that they are trying to run their normal businesses.

Trish, back to you.

REGAN: Well, it's their fault. Thank you very much, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Thank you.

REGAN: Joining me right now for more analysis, "Bullseye Brief" Publisher and Founder and Author, Adam Johnson, along with Belpointe Chief Strategist, David Nelson.

Is this going to be the end of Mark Zuckerberg?

That will be the day. Liz Claman, over to you. Down, gosh, 109.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I know, exactly. So, we have more than 250-point gain earlier gone.

END

Paul Ryan Denies Resignation Report; DOJ and AT&T Face Off2018-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:47:35ZLexisNexisFacebook Under Fire; Markets Mixed, Stocks Swinging Around Wildly; Kim Jong-un's China Visit; 2020 Census to Include Question about Citizenship?; Russia Vows Retaliation; Rep. Paul Ryan Denies Resignation Report; DOJ and AT&T Face OffLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Welcome back, Trish.

TRISH REGAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Thanks, Neil. Good to be back. Anyway, we've got a brief jumping session right now all over the place.

Breaking news, everyone, we've got Dow that's swinging back and forth, in and out in negative territory. It was up quite a bit earlier in the session, more than 200 now. Down to the flat line and now back up 50.

Investors are continuing to weigh basically the impact of the Trump administration's aggressive approach to China. They're not sure how it's all been to turn out. We're going to dive in to that over the next hour. So you can think about how you should be interpreting this news and what is going to mean for the market.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. It is great to be back all the way from Hawaii. I'll have a little more on that at the end of the show.

But meanwhile, let's talk about this trade war that everybody is so fearful about. I'll tell you, they're starting to basically come to grips with it. You've got fears are starting to ease. You're starting to see that the U.S. and China begin negotiations to address the tensions that had rocked global markets in recent weeks.

Investors are still trying to digest of the news at last to record sell- off, which is followed by a sharp rebound, nice to see yesterday. And we're going to be watching here all this drama that's unfolding right up until the closing bell. But I will ask yet again, are these markets overreacting? I think so. We've got some intel.

Plus, Facebook woes continue to pile on as U.S. officials say they are investigating the social network over its controversial privacy policies. And Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg out there finally feeling a little bit of heat. Now reports say he will testify before Congress. Is this beginning or the end for this company, for the Facebook founder? We have more coming up.

But first, back to our top story, this trade dispute with China. Will investors give President Trump a fair deal in terms of these markets? Will China give him a fair deal in terms of trade?

Joining me right now, Hudson Institute Senior Fellow, Michael Pillsbury, along with our very own Charles Payne. It's good to see you both.

Michael, I'll start with you. You know, look, people say the Trump administration is anti-free trade. It seems like kind of a drastic, drastic criticism, especially, I think, if you allow China to continue on the path it is you're going to wake up a decade from now, we're going to be the next France. They're going to be the hegemonic power in the world taking the place of the USA. So, with that in mind, what needs to happen so that things start to shake out in a more fair way?

MICHAEL PILLSBURY, SENIOR FELLOW, HUDSON INSTITUTE: Well, the first thing is China has got to take President Trump seriously, and they've done that. I think they've made some fairly major concessions in the last few days. That's probably why the market is calming down.

President Trump did not really declare a trade war at all. He had very, very limited measures, measures that were talked about for many years. The only thing is he's actually doing it, instead of just talking about it. But I don't see a really harsh pushback from the Chinese.

Their turnoffs against the steel and aluminum tariffs were very small, $3 billion to match $3 billion. They haven't only replied to this yet. But they have certainly offered to negotiate, and so some very conciliatory things almost an apology, Trish, where they say, "We were willing to open up our market, we're willing to open up some more sectors to foreign investment." So, I think, as you say, it's been really exaggerated.

And President Trump, he's probably showing that he's a master negotiator here. He's preserving his ties with China, which he needs for North Korea and getting their attention to start these negotiations. So, overall, I think, it's a pretty optimistic outcome over the last three or four days. It could have gone much differently.

REGAN: Charles, one of the things that frustrated me about China and has over the last number of years since I've, frankly, been following all of this is that China really does take advantage of us and U.S. companies. And you know what? The CEOs, they don't care because they want access to that Chinese market because it's going to be great for their quarterly results.

CHARLES PAYNE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Right.

REGAN: And, frankly, President Obama didn't really care so much either because, I think, there's been such a concentration by so many in Washington on the next election, much like CEOs are focused on the next quarter's results that they don't appreciate the context of what's going on here. They don't appreciate how this is all going to affect our population down the road, our kids, Charles, if we allow China to continue stealing our technology and making such onerous demands on our companies.

PAYNE: You know, I agree with you 1000 percent. Now, listen, everyone gives a lip service. You know, there are endless articles where Jack Lew, you know, was livid about the circumstances and he talked about them --

PILLSBURY: That's right.

PAYNE: -- but they never offered solutions. They never had any sort of real threat against China that will make China curb their predatory actions. And let's face it, when China joined the World Trade Organization that was going to make them a legitimate player and follow all the rules. Of course, they didn't follow the rules. And who can blame China? They are.

You started to show up talking about their grand ambitions. They do have grand ambitions. And right now, by 2026, their economy could be bigger than ours.

And, you know, couple India and other Asian nations, and America starts to falls into the sort of zone where Europe is. And Europe can't turn around. They're done unfortunately. And so, if we're going to make a stand, we have to make a stand at this very point.

And, you know, one example I like to use Trish, is a G.M. Buick division has an SUV, the Envision. The Envision is only made in Singapore, right, in Shanghai, rather. And it's exported to this country. It was a big hit last year.

Now, that's great for General Motors and their shareholders. It's great for the American consumers who probably get a pretty good car at a pretty good price. And it's great for the Chinese worker who made it. There's one person missing from the equation and that's the American factory worker, auto worker who might have otherwise had made this product. And that's why there's a different bifurcation.

You know, China hasn't pushed back but Wall Street has pushed back. Last week, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, every day at 2:00, approximately 2:00, a gigantic sell program went off. Ultimately it took 1200 Dow points out of the market. There was no new news at 2:00.

Every single day at that point we saw the markets fell off dramatically. I think Wall Street has been pushing back on this a lot harder than China has.

REGAN: Look, you know, Michael, I get Wall Street, but what I think is a critical here is that we not look at the day-to-day, and I would remind traders not to look at the day-to-day because I'll tell you, 10 years from now you're going to wake up and had a heck of a problem on your hand if you don't deal with the China stuff now. So if we tick a little pain along the way, we will be better off. It is mind-boggling to me.

I mean, they're out creating their version of the WTO. They're investing in many economies in Latin America, in Pakistan, in Iran --

PILLSBURY: Africa.

REGAN: -- or Russia, Africa as well, places that they can seek commodity resources in. I mean, they have a very definite plan to be the world's largest economic power and quite perhaps possibly the world's largest military power. So, if we don't wake up and deal with that at some point, Michael, I think we're going to have much bigger problems on our hands than 600-point drop in the Dow.

PILLSBURY: I agree. I agree with Charles, too. As you know, I wrote a book about this three years ago, which is widely criticized as being alarmist.

And now President Trump has not only accepted some of the premises, he's released a much better report, if I may say so, than my book just last week. It's 250 pages long. Example after example after example of what President Obama used to call the "gangsterization" of our companies. That's why President Trump is moving forward on several fronts. It's not just tariffs. It's this new suit at the WTO in Geneva.

There's number of other measures. And, frankly, there is bipartisan support for what he is doing. Senator Chuck Schumer is often seen as enemy of the President, very quickly endorsed President Trump last Thursday on the tightening up on technology purchases here in the United States.

The bill has attracted the co-sponsorship of Dianne Feinstein who would be happy to call a progressive liberal, I think. So this problem has gone on for so long that just these limited steps seems to be producing a lot of bipartisan support. That's why the day-to-day fluctuation in the market really kind of a shortsighted. And some people who didn't listen are probably losing money now.

REGAN: Yes. Well, they'll make it up. Very quickly, Charles, there are some examples, I think, out there of Chinese companies now looking to invest in the U.S. because, look, we're not going to continue with the current status quo.

PAYNE: Absolutely. Well, you know, two news items today. One is a smaller company, but it's really important, JinkoSolar, the fourth largest solar manufacturer in the world that Chinese company probably will be breaking ground here. It becomes official today in Jacksonville, $50 million project, 400,000 square feet.

Here is the most important thing. This comes after President Trump levied the 30 percent tariff on their product. So now they're going to bring and manufacturing here and of course --

REGAN: They're going to bring it here?

PAYNE: -- we know Foxconn, of course, is building out big time. They made an acquisition today. And while there are pros and cons to it, people need to pay attention.

REGAN: Michael, Charles, good to see you guys.

PAYNE: You got it.

REGAN: Thank you so much. Good perspective. And make sure, everyone, watch Charles on "Making Money" tonight, 6:00 p.m. Eastern right here on Fox Business.

Turning to our other top story, Facebook says it will not confirm reports that CEO, Mark Zuckerberg will testify before Congress about how Facebook collects and stores user data. But Mr. Zuckerberg says he will not appear before the U.K. parliament. All of this as we have uncovered video from eight years ago of Apple co-founder, Steve Jobs, warning Mark Zuckerberg and other tech CEOs about user privacy.

For the latest, let's go right now to Deirdre Bolton who has been following the story from day one. Deirdre.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Trish, Facebook is under pressure. It is facing investigations from 37 states attorneys general, including tech-heavy states California, Massachusetts, New York. It is also now facing specific lawsuits just this morning from counties, such as IllinoisCook County, that includes Chicago and surrounding areas.

So, basically those areas are just joining this legal fight against Facebook and Cambridge Analytica over the misuse of data scraped from social media profiles claiming that both companies violated state fraud law. So that is the paperwork from Cook County, Illinois. So this lawsuit claims that Cambridge Analytica tricked Facebook users with quizzes and that Facebook knew, this is really serious, Trish, this accusation, and did nothing to stop it.

Now, as you point it out, Steve Jobs, seemed to have a premonition about this relationship between tech and privacy getting more cloudy. Here is what he said eight years ago.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVE JOBS, CO-FOUNDER, APPLE: The Silicon Valley is not monolithic. We've always had a very different view of privacy than some of our colleagues in the Valley. We take privacy extremely seriously. And some people want to share more data than other people do.

Ask them. Ask them every time. Make them tell you to stop asking them, if they get tired of you asking them. Let them know precisely what you're going to do with their data.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: I'm sure Mark Zuckerberg wishes he had seen that or heard that or paid attention because that Cook County lawsuit specifically states "Facebook is not a social media company, it is the largest data mining operation in existence." It further claims that Facebook worked to keep developers on its platform plying them with sensitive data at the expense of its users' privacy.

The Federal Trade Commission also investigating Facebook. It signaled today that its probe of the company is broad. So that's a key word because it's never what a company wants to hear. It implies impending regulation.

Mark Zuckerberg may also testify on Capitol Hill not clear yet. He has been invited to a hearing on April 10th. If he goes, he's going to be asked questions about Facebook's policies regarding protection and monitoring of consumer data.

Senator Grassley is the one who issue the invitation, also extended the same to Google's CEO and Twitter's CEO. But essentially, Trish, this opens up huge questions for big tech, for privacy, for potential regulation. All of these companies right away, they have to spend more money on their legal teams. Probably Mark Zuckerberg has an extra direct report because of this and it is certainly going to be a distraction to the way that they are trying to run their normal businesses.

Trish, back to you.

REGAN: Well, it's their fault. Thank you very much, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Thank you.

REGAN: Joining me right now for more analysis, "Bullseye Brief" Publisher and Founder and Author, Adam Johnson, along with Belpointe Chief Strategist, David Nelson.

Is this going to be the end of Mark Zuckerberg?

ADAM JOHNSON, AUTHOR, "BULLSEYE BRIEF" PUBLISHER AND AUTHOR: It's starting to look like it. And I tell you something, Trish, there's a real trust problem which Zuckerberg himself said when he went on CNN in his t-shirt looking all dough-eyed for all of us to try to sound contrite. The problem is we don't necessarily trust that our data is safe. That's number one.

Number two, we don't necessarily trust that what's in our news feed is accurate because of the fake news. And number three, it's kind of hard for me, and I would imagine a lot of other people, to necessarily trust a company that takes all our data, all our hard work, our intellectual capital, all the effort that we put into posting, sells that to other people for billions of dollars, and all we get back in return is likes. I'm sorry, but that doesn't breed trust.

REGAN: You have a plan for that.

JOHNSON: Yes.

REGAN: You have some suggestions to Mr. Zuckerberg.

JOHNSON: I do.

REGAN: Let's get to that in a second. But first of all, in terms of this company, you know, look, I was on vacation this week. And I used Facebook more than I would on a regular basis because, you know, I'm posting pictures of the kids.

JOHNSON: Sure.

REGAN: And all of that good stuff. And I thought, you know, I don't know if I want to be on this right now. I don't know if anybody wants to be on this right now because of these violations into our privacy, which, you know, he's a little contrite there, saying, "Oh, yes, shouldn't happen. It's our responsibility."

This is a company, David, that makes money off being able to target ads so specifically. They're going to want to know everything they can about Trish Regan, Adam Johnson, and David Nelson.

DAVID NELSON, CHIEF STRATEGIST, BELPOINTE: Yes.

REGAN: So that they can target those ads. And I don't know if any of us should be OK with that.

NELSON: Sure. Big data is big money and that's what this is about. And I think what we're finding out is there's nothing social in that social media. This is a data mining operation like --

JOHNSON: It's one-sided, right?

NELSON: -- it's kind of one-sided. They have the data and they use it. And for Mark Zuckerberg not, you know, agreeing to appear, he obviously has aspirations for something beyond Facebook. He did a tour in the country, almost in campaign style.

And nobody looks good in front of the Senate subcommittee. You start to look like Michael Corleone and you try to explain that you're just a CEO of an olive oil company. He's trying to deflect this, putting the CTO, those Chief Technology Officers, in front of Congress or parliament. That's not going to cut it. People want some answers.

And I think there are going to be some solutions. I was wrong last week when I thought that with the genie out of the bottle, this business model wouldn't change. Obviously it's going to change. Regulation is going to change it.

REGAN: Well, yes, I mean, it has to change. And you're right, I mean, the news feed being fake, our information being compromised. You think there's a way for them to fix this so that their "users," you wouldn't even call them that, would actually have some skin in the game?

JOHNSON: Right.

REGAN: How would you change that?

JOHNSON: Well, I cut a video yesterday and I posted out on Twitter and Facebook and link. Then it got a little bit of traction. I said, "Stop calling us users for starters, Mark. Why don't you start calling us partners and actually make us partners by giving us the same kind of upside that the cryptocurrency markets give us." In other words, they in all their brilliance over at Facebook have all these algorithms.

"So why don't you use your algorithms, Mark, to figure out what makes a great post? Maybe it's a number of likes, cute puppies, thoughtful social commentary. Whatever it is, use all of that to award our posts with face coins and then let us redeem face coin on Facebook for goods and services. And by the way, if we don't want to do that let's trade it, the same way we trade bitcoin and get money for it." In other words, create a rewards point system so that we are partners. And that is interesting --

REGAN: But that would cost some money.

JOHNSON: -- yes, exactly.

REGAN: It would cost some money if they're the ones putting the good and services.

JOHNSON: That's right.

REGAN: But the membership, you know, you think about --

NELSON: But regulations cost money.

REGAN: -- right, they give you membership rewards or these credit card companies, or hotel companies, airline companies, if you spend a certain amount of money with them, or fly with them, or travel with them you get something in return.

JOHNSON: And Facebook doesn't give us anything.

REGAN: They use all our contact.

NELSON: In fact, they're stealing and that's it and we're not getting a dime for it.

JOHNSON: All we get are likes.

NELSON: We're giving it to them. I don't know if they're stealing it.

JOHNSON: Yes.

NELSON: But I don't know a face coin is going to work. But certainly, you know, a rewards program something like that could work. There's actually some business models out there, seeking out.

There's a place where financial advisors go out and put outposts. And if they have enough viewers on that they actually get paid for that. They would get paid for our likes. And maybe as of dislike, maybe you get some points taken away. Maybe that would eliminate some of those occupy Democrat political, you know, hand grenades that I see post in my Facebook page.

JOHNSON: Now you're talking like the SAT test where you get penalized for random answers. But they can figure this stuff out. They have the algorithms

REGAN: Well, yes, they certainly can. I don't think there has been any willingness to. We haven't even started about how the, you know, ISIS terrorists want to use social media.

NELSON: The ramifications beyond Facebook are pretty large.

JOHNSON: Right.

REGAN: Right.

NELSON: This affects Google and so many others.

REGAN: Good stuff. Adam, David, thank you so much.

NELSON: Thanks, Trish.

REGAN: All right. Kim Jong-un reportedly making a secret trip to China, his first foreign trip since taking power of the kingdom there in 2011. What does this visit mean for the U.S.? We're on it. Stay with us. We'll see you here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right. Everyone, get this, a heavily guarded mysterious train rolled into Beijing on Monday. And officials believe that it may have been carrying none other than North Korean dictator, Kim Jong-un. A visit to the Chinese capital would mark Kim's first trip beyond North Korean borders since taking power back in 2011. So if these reports are true, why did he make the trip? Why did he make it now?

Joining me with analysis, "Nuclear Showdown" Author, Gordon Chang. Gordon, always good to see you. You are the guy to talk to about North Korea and China. So what your take on this? Did it happen and why did he do it?

GORDON CHANG, AUTHOR, "NUCLEAR SHOWDOWN": Yes, I think it certainly happened. And I think the reason why Kim went to Beijing was because Beijing demanded that he go there.

You got to remember that Kim was going to make his first foreign trip to South Korea, to go south of the military demarcation line in the demilitarize zone to the peace house, which is in South Korea. And then his second foreign trip was going to be seeing President Trump. The Chinese realized they were being marginalized. And so, essentially what they said to Kim was, "You come to Beijing or else."

REGAN: What do you think will come of this?

CHANG: I don't know what's going to happen with the Trump-Kim summit. But I think that it was very good for President Trump to do that because he is cutting out the Chinese. And the Chinese over this century have really been a maligned influence. They have been helping the North Korean nuclear weapons effort as well as ballistic missile program.

And what Trump decided to do is he was not going to put up with that, he was going to talk to Kim Jong-un directly. And you've got to remember, Trish, this is occurring at the same time as the trade disputes.

Now, the Chinese have heard American Presidents threaten trade actions, but they haven't really seen anyone carry through. And President Trump is carrying through. And the Chinese right now are probably pretty bewildered. They got both Kim and Trump giving them a hard time.

REGAN: Simultaneously, you have John Bolton now as part of the administration as well and he, Ambassador Bolton has made very clear, certainly to me in the past, he would like to see the reunification of the North Korean peninsula and one would have to assume that Kim Jong-un would be on the losing side of that deal. So, are the Chinese now being caught off guard or a bit more nervous? How does that affect everything that's going on because they may be looking at it and saying, "Gosh, you know, the U.S. is playing tough now on trade?" Maybe somehow trying to court Kim Jong-un in a way that we don't understand, and in fact, the U.S. may wind up having a much bigger presence right next door to us than we anticipated, Gordon?

CHANG: Yes, you know, John Bolton as National security advisor and Mike Pompeo as Secretary of State really round out of the war Cabinet. And, you know, you look at what Bolton said about the main problem in the world, it's China and Russia. And so, Beijing right now has got to understand that they've got a new sheriff in town, and that Bolton is going to push Trump in directions that Trump would go anyway.

You know, Trump started out his administration by trying to placate the Chinese, bringing them on board, getting them to help on North Korea. They didn't do that. So, you know, right now, you have to a consensus --

REGAN: And he said he was a little disappointed in that. That he had hoped to get more cooperation from China.

CHANG: -- yes. And we know from the President's tweets that he is not only -- of course, he was first disappointed but now angry and frustrated. You have Bolton coming in, Pompeo coming in. It's a new landscape for the Chinese.

And right now, they're seeing something that they have never faced before.

REGAN: Meaning?

CHANG: Well, meaning that there's now an administration that is willing to hold them responsible for really predatory mercantilist and dangerous activities around the world. And so, you know, they're seeing that the U.S. is going to impose costs on China and deal with China as well as Moscow in a way that we haven't seen since the end of the Cold War. So I think you have now in Beijing, people are saying who lost America, as a "Washington Post" correspondent recently wrote about a week ago.

REGAN: Well, it's about time. They've been getting away with a whole lot for much too long.

CHANG: It's a about time.

REGAN: Anyway, Gordon Chang, it's good to see you. Appreciate your analysis.

CHANG: Thanks, Trish.

REGAN: For the first time in 70 years, the 2020 census is going to include a question about citizenship. Democrats are blasting this move, but is it legal? We have some intel as the market trades up 25 points right now on the Dow. See you right here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: And on the market, it took a dip into negative territory. So, we're watching it very carefully. It's been a rather volatile session all over the place here.

Investors are still trying to come to grips with what's exactly this trade dispute with China will mean.

In the mean time, we're watching another story here and that's the 2020 census, which is now expected to include a question about citizenship status. The population count take in every 10 years is required by the Constitutions and it is use to determine the number of seats each state has in the House. So, it's important from that perspective as well as how federal funds are distributed.

Democrats are condemning this move saying it would actually discourage immigrants from responding, which would cause a population undercount and therefore they wouldn't able to have as many representatives, say, from state like California. California's attorney general is suing the Trump Administration saying and "including a citizenship question on the 2020 census is not a bad idea, it is illegal."

Joining me right now is Fox News Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano, with his sense of whether it is, in fact, legal or not. Where do you come out?

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: It is legal to ask because the federal government has a legitimate interest in knowing that but the government cannot compel the answer from the person asked because we have the right to remain silent.

REGAN: OK. So then the California A.G. really doesn't have much of a case.

NAPOLITANO: First of all, it's premature because Congress hasn't decided this yet. This is just a proposal from the Commerce Department, which must file its proposal by the end of this week and they filed it last night.

Congress is not in session for the next two weeks. They're going to debate this all over again when Congress is back there. But the only thing under the Constitution of the government can compel any answer to is how many human beings lives in this house and how many bathrooms you have? What is your education, what is your nationality, and what is your citizenship? Again, it can ask but it can't punish him for not answering.

REGAN: OK. So, it seems to me then, it's fair to ask the question and it's obviously an individual decision as to whether or not they want to respond. But assuming that California is right and all the people that are here illegally decline to answer the question, does population count go down and therefore does the number of representatives coming from a state like California go down?

NAPOLITANO: That is a great question. And that would be exquisitely unfair to the rest of the country if California where to get more representatives in the House of Representatives because of more illegal or undocumented persons living in California. That is not the intent of the census and that is not the purpose of the headcount. So the Federal Government is going to have to find some other way to determine who is legitimately, lawfully residing in California without compelling people to answer.

Now, I think a lot of people will answer anyway. I don't know if they'll answer truthfully or not. I think the Democrats do have an argument to make the people here unlawfully are not going to answer truthfully because they'll think it's going to trigger their deportation although this questionnaires are anonymous.

REGAN: Right. Different then, let's say, it was back when, you know, during World War II and you were making a point to me off-camera that there were times in history that we have used the census --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

REGAN: -- to actually find people?

NAPOLITANO: Yes. The Roosevelt Administration in the census of 1940 not only asked if you're a citizen and asked your nationality. And then when FDR and his colleagues decided to incarcerate Japanese-Americans, they had the data to find them.

Congress was so outraged by this. But in 1947, FDR is dead, the war is over. That it enacted legislation prohibiting asking nationality but did not prohibit asking citizenship.

REGAN: All right. Well, let's see what happens.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

REGAN: Thank you, Judge. Good to see you.

NAPOLITANO: Good to see you. Welcome back.

REGAN: Thank you. It's good to be back. Wow, lots of news going on.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

REGAN: You could say that. Any day, any week, Russia is vowing to retaliate after President Trump expels 60 diplomats from the United States. What will that include and will this finally put an end to talk that Trump is too soft on Vladmir Putin?

Plus, we are following these markets. We can see we've been all over the place now, up 13 points, just straddling really the flat line here. What is driving this? Is it really concerns about a trade war with China? We've got more after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: This is an interesting story, everyone. Russia vowing to respond harshly to the U.S. expulsion of 60 Russian diplomats. Their foreign ministry even accusing the U.S. of blackmailing other countries to expel Russian diplomat.

Our Ashley Webster has been all over the story, of course, it starts in the U.K. --

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: It does.

REGAN: -- with nerve gas in an ex-Russian spy.

WEBSTER: I mean, on outrageous attack of a nerve agent on British soil, that's a Russian nerve agent. I think what's come out of this is a couple things. I think Vladmir Putin has totally miscalculated what's happened here.

The Brits, I think there is a theory out there, Trish, that Britain is leaving the E.U., that there's a perception that Theresa May is a weakened leader and that that has propelled the Russians to take these kinds of steps, to test the resolve. If that is the case, terrible mistake because look what happened, 27 countries now have kicked out more than 140 Russian diplomats. The U.N. expelling seven Russian diplomats, we just heard in reaction to this. And I think it is certainly hurt Putin in certain ways.

There are those in Moscow that when they're going to look him, they're going to say, "Hmm, that wasn't a very good move."

REAGAN: He wants to be -- right, on the world international stage and basically he's losing that starring role by getting all of his diplomats expelled but one would understand. I mean, why do you want people in your country that are capable of --

WEBSTER: Spying?

REGAN: -- doing what these people did in the U.K.?

WEBSTER: Of course, everybody does it. And the U.K., especially we've had like 12 deaths in the U.K. that have Russian links.

REGAN: And we also know that more than 100 people were exposed to this nerve gas agent.

WEBSTER: Yes, in this small town in the West of England, in Salisbury, which, you know, the health authorities said, "No, you'll be OK." Then they said, "You may want to stop wiping your cell phones and washing your clothing." It was amid to this day, there very, you know, there are quite a few people just say, "Well, I don't know. What are the health risks of this?"

But the bottom line is the other point I wanted to make about Putin and Russia is this is the biggest blow to their spy network on the west, multinational blows since the Cold War. I mean, that has severely hurt their spy network.

Look at the U.S., 60 diplomats gone, 48. The closing of consulate in Seattle, because it's close to Boeing, it's close to a submarine base there. That hurts. That definitely hurts Russia's spy network. It's not going to kill it but it's going to make it pretty painful.

REGAN: Now, they're trying to retaliate.

WEBSTER: They will.

REGAN: Meaning?

WEBSTER: Meaning that they'll do it tit-to-tat. The bottom line is Russia is the big loser here.

REGAN: Yes. I would say and, you know, I wonder how this sits with some members of the Democratic Party that keeps saying this administration is an easy on Russia.

WEBSTER: Yes.

REGAN: You're telling me this is the biggest hit to their spy network --

WEBSTER: Since the Cold War.

REGAN: -- since the Cold War.

WEBSTER: Yes. It is significant and I think Putin totally did not expect the United States to kick out 60 diplomats. That's a high number.

The U.K. kicked out 23. That was a very aggressive move. It was appropriate, I believe. But it certainly was, I think, a shot to Moscow.

REGAN: Yes. And more and more countries are following the same way, Ashley.

WEBSTER: Yes, good. Good.

REGAN: Good. Ashley, thank you so much.

We got the markets mixed right now although we are trading higher by about 57 points there on the Dow. Stocks swinging around here rather wildly but doesn't this always happen right around 2:00?

Nicole Petallides has more, down at the New York Stock Exchange for us.

Hey, Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Hey, Trish. As you said, we've seen the volatility this afternoon, the most afternoons around this time gets pretty wild. Right now, we're up 41 points, off our earlier highs but it's nice to see some arrows up, with up arrow after last week where we saw the big sell-off of more than 1400 points.

Yesterday, nearly 700 point gain and we're holding on to the green just for the Dow. The NASDAQ and the S&P 500 have moved into the red.

Tech stocks, also financial stocks are coming under some pressure. Well, financials are mixed, I should say, tech, energy, and industrials are under pressure.

I wanted to get to general electric. The Buffett bounce. There is speculation that Warren Buffett's Berkshire has a way may be getting back into G.E. after jumping out last year.

Of course, G.E., over the last 12 months down 56 percent. It's been a big dog. And now there is word that they might be back in in amassing a big stake.

Now, of course, General Electric, no comment. Nobody is commenting. But look at the stock, though, it's up 5.5 percent today. So, we'll see what happens there but it's certainly getting a nice big boost for today. It's the worst performer on the Dow this year.

And then just take a pick at that winners of Dow Jones Industrial Average today, at this moment and that would be Nike, Proctor & Gamble, Verizon, Pfizer. You see some up arrows here as everybody just takes a breather about those trade war worries at least for the moment.

Back to you, Trish.

REGAN: I encourage them to take a big breather, a big one because we have to deal with this now, head-on, or we're going to see a real problem 10 years from now that we don't want.

Anyway, Nicole Petallides, thank you so much.

Paul Ryan, everyone, is forced to deny that he is stepping down as House Speaker after a resignation rumor goes rampant. It does open the door to this big question, are both parties in need of new blood, new leadership, as we head into the midterms?

Our panel debates it for you next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Ryan's office said the Speaker is not resigning. This, after reports surface last night the Republican leader may be stepping down. One Congressman even suggested that Whip Steve Scalise would be elected to replace.

All these rumors out there and, well, they're just rumors but they give beg the question. Is it time for a shake-up in leadership for both parties?

Joining me right now, Fox News Contributor, Jessica Tarlov, and American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun. I think you two are going to be in agreement on this one

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think that's will the first time.

REGAN: Right.

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: Maybe.

REGAN: Well, let me start with you, Jessica. The Democratic Party, and I think this is obvious to everyone given all the Marie Antoinette-like comments Nancy Pelosi has been making, do they need a shake-up?

TARLOV: I think they're going to end up with a shake-up. I am a big fan of Nancy Pelosi. I think she has been long-term wonderful for the party.

REGAN: You're one and only?

TARLOV: What? No, no, there are like 10 of us. No, what she did was getting the ACA passed and she's also done a prolific fund-raiser for the party, which we all know is incredibly important. Says a lot about that. But with the leadership challenge the last time around from Tim Ryan and with people like Conor Lamb getting elected all over the country, I think there is going to be shift and a lot of pressure to go younger and more progressive.

REGAN: Yes. I think that we are seeing that and it's probably the healthy thing for that party. Now, in terms of the Republicans, one of the biggest complaints, I know you have had, Ned, is that Republicans ala Paul Ryan, are not fully on board with the Trump administration's agenda and they're very reluctant to come around on a lot of things. With that in mind, do they also need a change in leadership?

RYUN: Well, I will say this, I mean, these rumors of Paul Ryan resigning are fake news. I talked with multiple members of Congress and they said fake news.

One of them asked him point-blank, "Are you going to resign?" And he said, "Absolutely not." So, I don't think you're going to see a leadership change anytime soon on the House side.

But, Trish, I think this whole omnibus bill is a sign that Congress is broken. And if you want to talk about leadership that needs to change, Congress is broken because Mitch McConnell is basically letting the Democrats help run the Senate with him.

I honestly think some days, Trish, that we have joint majority leaders with Chuck Schumer and Mitch McConnell and one ruling class swamp party. Because let's face it, a lot of GOP Senators they quite frankly like this broken Congress. They can help out their crony special interests buddies and tuck away the special earmarks in 2200 page bills that nobody reads. And all of a sudden, look what happens, we have 1.3 trillion omnibus bills.

So, if you were to ask me, is leadership change needed? Yes, absolutely.

The House actually has been operating like it should be. The Senate is completely broken and I blame Mitch McConnell for it.

REGAN: You do. Do you think that the Democrats should also make a shift then?

RYUN: No, please, dear God. Do not dethrone the queen of San Francisco.

TARLOV: That's always what Republican say.

RYUN: Do not dethrone the queen of San Francisco. She is great for us. She is writing our attack ads. Between she and Hillary with crumbs, deplorable, backwards Trump voters. I mean, this, in all seriousness, though Trish, this is a problem for Democrat in those 10 red states where you have Democrat's Senators running for re-election.

Hillary and Nancy Pelosi and are writing Republican attack ads for the midterms.

TARLOV: Yes, I would add to that, and I agree with you when you said Claire McCaskill being incredibly outspoken about Hillary Clinton's comments.

RYUN: Yes.

TARLOV: And saying you shouldn't insult anybody but certainly don't be insulting anyone in my state. You know, it's just in a deep red state. And we do have 10 up for re-election.

I would ask this on the Paul Ryan side of things that there are kind of two sides to this coin. Yes, you ask him point-blank what's he is going to do but there have been a lot of surprise resignations.

Jason Chaffetz, I don't -- Trey Gowdy not going to run for re-election. There are a lot committee heads on the Republican side who are not going to run again. And we are forgetting as well, Paul Ryan didn't even want this job.

REGAN: That's right.

TARLOV: Remember, when he begrudgingly took in and he was like, well, I want to make sure that I can spend time with me family. So, under these circumstances when he's pushing forward an agenda that the President really doesn't have much interest in it, I can see why he might want to bow out gracefully before.

REGAN: It's kind of thankless job, right, Ned? I mean, you know, you either, you know, buy into what the President is doing, I think it's been hard for him. I think it's been hard for a lot of Republican there because they're kind of, "I don't know if I like this. I don't know if I like where it's going." And I worry, much as you do, I think, Ned, it's the swamp influence that they have --

RYUN: It is.

TARLOV: -- the ear of many corporations and lobbyists that have their own interests at stake. And so, suddenly everybody is saying, "Whoa, we have a huge trade war coming, thanks to President Trump and his administration." And so, they're fighting back against that. When we all know that if we don't start to confront the reality of what China is doing now, it's going to be our kids that are paying the price, Ned.

RYUN: Absolutely. You know, I think we're already -- China has already declared economic warfare on us. I think people just wake up to that fact. But no, you're right and, Trish, you've kind of alluded to this just now.

The interests of Corporate America in the American people, the American working class are not always aligns and the problem here that you see in Republican politics and I know even in Democrat politics, a lot of the big donors to these parties are from corporate interests. They are not aligned with American voter. So, there's no alignment between Trump with the outside devolve power from D.C., drain the swamp.

I mean, again, this omnibus bill had nothing to do with draining the swamp. It was actually feeding the swamp. It was a triumph from the swamp but it goes back to some of the structural problems with in party politics of who's actually footing the bill, who's funding things

And I tell you want? When it comes down to the down to leadership, there are a lot of people with corporate interests, special interests that are right there in your ear whispering, "You want to do this, you want next big check, you need to do this." And sadly, this is what continues to happen in D.C. year after year.

TARLOV: Yes, that is interesting, though, that you point that out about Corporate America not being on the same page as the American voter. When you saw the Republican bill with big slashes to the corporate tax rate but not to the individual --

REGAN: They gave individuals a great, great deal, too. The only individuals that --

TARLOV: -- a lot of people are not benefiting from that.

REGAN: -- we are high earner in New York and California.

RYUN: Jessica, no complaints.

TARLOV: Yes.

REGAN: But I would say, we need to do that on the corporate side. And they did give a pretty big one to the -- that's a story for another day.

TARLOV: Another segment.

REGAN: Thank you, Jessica.

TARLOV: Thanks, Trish. Welcome back.

REGAN: It's good to see you guys. It's good to be back.

Anyway, we're going to look at this because the court battle underway right now to decide the fate of AT&T and Time Warner is heating up. We're going to have some details for you next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Department of Justice is attempting to block the potential $85 billion merger between AT&T and Time Warner. They're in court today, right now.

For more, we're going to Connell McShane. Hey, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Well, hey, Trish. We have quite a face-off in the courtroom earlier today between Warren Schlichting, is a guys and Executive at Sling T.V., which own by Dish network, and an attorney for the company Daniel Petrocelli is representing AT&T and Time Warner.

Schlichting is a government witness. He testified yesterday here in court that Turner program and all the networks' Turner control, DCO, AT&T, CNN, all the rest, that it's a must for Sling and for Dish Network. But today, there was a challenge to that. That's the real question, coming up on the screen is, are these Turner Networks really must have programming?

Petrocelli was interesting in the way he did it. He used the quote from Charlie Ergen, the founder, kind of against his own employe saying, that he had said Ergen, "CNN may and must have programming in 20 years ago but it's not anymore. Schlichting response that, "I call that negotiating in the press." And they kind of have similar conversation, Trish, about sports programming and back and forth and went between the two.

As we move now into the afternoon session as Schlichting wraps up, we expect to hear from the government's next witness in this trial, which could be a very interesting witness and expected to be a hostile one, the Turner Chairman, John Martin. We'll see if any of his past words particularly in contract negotiations can be used against him.

That still to come report back later. But for now, back to you.

REGAN: All right, interesting stuff. Connell, Thank you so much.

I have to say, it's pretty good to be back. It's great to be back in FBN. I had a wonderful week off, a vacation with my family. We went all the way to Hawaii, believe or not and I wanted to show this because this is my daughter, Alexandra, and she begged us for surfing lessons.

She's only eight years old. You may have seen her on the show. She talked about her Brownie, Girl Scout cookie sales recently. Well, she was on that surfboard. Oh my goodness.

She got up on this thing and we thought ourselves, "Are we really good parents." She is quite a kid.

The other two were not as enthused about the surfing thing, I totally get it, Elizabeth and Jamie. I don't think you could get me on one of those things either, I'll be honest. People asked me if I took that video. I'm like, "Are you kidding me? Me on a surfboard?

That will be the day. Liz Claman, over to you. Down, gosh, 109.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I know, exactly. So, we have more than 250-point gain earlier gone.

END

Paul Ryan Denies Resignation Report; DOJ and AT&T Face OffLanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Welcome back, Trish.

TRISH REGAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS HOST: Thanks, Neil. Good to be back. Anyway, we've got a brief jumping session right now all over the place.

Breaking news, everyone, we've got Dow that's swinging back and forth, in and out in negative territory. It was up quite a bit earlier in the session, more than 200 now. Down to the flat line and now back up 50.

Investors are continuing to weigh basically the impact of the Trump administration's aggressive approach to China. They're not sure how it's all been to turn out. We're going to dive in to that over the next hour. So you can think about how you should be interpreting this news and what is going to mean for the market.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome to THE INTELLIGENCE REPORT. It is great to be back all the way from Hawaii. I'll have a little more on that at the end of the show.

But meanwhile, let's talk about this trade war that everybody is so fearful about. I'll tell you, they're starting to basically come to grips with it. You've got fears are starting to ease. You're starting to see that the U.S. and China begin negotiations to address the tensions that had rocked global markets in recent weeks.

Investors are still trying to digest of the news at last to record sell- off, which is followed by a sharp rebound, nice to see yesterday. And we're going to be watching here all this drama that's unfolding right up until the closing bell. But I will ask yet again, are these markets overreacting? I think so. We've got some intel.

Plus, Facebook woes continue to pile on as U.S. officials say they are investigating the social network over its controversial privacy policies. And Facebook CEO, Mark Zuckerberg out there finally feeling a little bit of heat. Now reports say he will testify before Congress. Is this beginning or the end for this company, for the Facebook founder? We have more coming up.

But first, back to our top story, this trade dispute with China. Will investors give President Trump a fair deal in terms of these markets? Will China give him a fair deal in terms of trade?

Joining me right now, Hudson Institute Senior Fellow, Michael Pillsbury, along with our very own Charles Payne. It's good to see you both.

REGAN: I encourage them to take a big breather, a big one because we have to deal with this now, head-on, or we're going to see a real problem 10 years from now that we don't want.

Anyway, Nicole Petallides, thank you so much.

Paul Ryan, everyone, is forced to deny that he is stepping down as House Speaker after a resignation rumor goes rampant. It does open the door to this big question, are both parties in need of new blood, new leadership, as we head into the midterms?

Our panel debates it for you next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Ryan's office said the Speaker is not resigning. This, after reports surface last night the Republican leader may be stepping down. One Congressman even suggested that Whip Steve Scalise would be elected to replace.

All these rumors out there and, well, they're just rumors but they give beg the question. Is it time for a shake-up in leadership for both parties?

Joining me right now, Fox News Contributor, Jessica Tarlov, and American Majority CEO, Ned Ryun. I think you two are going to be in agreement on this one

JESSICA TARLOV, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think that's will the first time.

REGAN: Right.

NED RYUN, AMERICAN MAJORITY CEO: Maybe.

REGAN: Well, let me start with you, Jessica. The Democratic Party, and I think this is obvious to everyone given all the Marie Antoinette-like comments Nancy Pelosi has been making, do they need a shake-up?

TARLOV: I think they're going to end up with a shake-up. I am a big fan of Nancy Pelosi. I think she has been long-term wonderful for the party.

REGAN: You're one and only?

TARLOV: What? No, no, there are like 10 of us. No, what she did was getting the ACA passed and she's also done a prolific fund-raiser for the party, which we all know is incredibly important. Says a lot about that. But with the leadership challenge the last time around from Tim Ryan and with people like Conor Lamb getting elected all over the country, I think there is going to be shift and a lot of pressure to go younger and more progressive.

REGAN: Yes. I think that we are seeing that and it's probably the healthy thing for that party. Now, in terms of the Republicans, one of the biggest complaints, I know you have had, Ned, is that Republicans ala Paul Ryan, are not fully on board with the Trump administration's agenda and they're very reluctant to come around on a lot of things. With that in mind, do they also need a change in leadership?

RYUN: Well, I will say this, I mean, these rumors of Paul Ryan resigning are fake news. I talked with multiple members of Congress and they said fake news.

One of them asked him point-blank, "Are you going to resign?" And he said, "Absolutely not." So, I don't think you're going to see a leadership change anytime soon on the House side.

But, Trish, I think this whole omnibus bill is a sign that Congress is broken. And if you want to talk about leadership that needs to change, Congress is broken because Mitch McConnell is basically letting the Democrats help run the Senate with him.

I honestly think some days, Trish, that we have joint majority leaders with Chuck Schumer and Mitch McConnell and one ruling class swamp party. Because let's face it, a lot of GOP Senators they quite frankly like this broken Congress. They can help out their crony special interests buddies and tuck away the special earmarks in 2200 page bills that nobody reads. And all of a sudden, look what happens, we have 1.3 trillion omnibus bills.

So, if you were to ask me, is leadership change needed? Yes, absolutely.

The House actually has been operating like it should be. The Senate is completely broken and I blame Mitch McConnell for it.

REGAN: You do. Do you think that the Democrats should also make a shift then?

RYUN: No, please, dear God. Do not dethrone the queen of San Francisco.

TARLOV: That's always what Republican say.

RYUN: Do not dethrone the queen of San Francisco. She is great for us. She is writing our attack ads. Between she and Hillary with crumbs, deplorable, backwards Trump voters. I mean, this, in all seriousness, though Trish, this is a problem for Democrat in those 10 red states where you have Democrat's Senators running for re-election.

Hillary and Nancy Pelosi and are writing Republican attack ads for the midterms.

TARLOV: Yes, I would add to that, and I agree with you when you said Claire McCaskill being incredibly outspoken about Hillary Clinton's comments.

RYUN: Yes.

TARLOV: And saying you shouldn't insult anybody but certainly don't be insulting anyone in my state. You know, it's just in a deep red state. And we do have 10 up for re-election.

I would ask this on the Paul Ryan side of things that there are kind of two sides to this coin. Yes, you ask him point-blank what's he is going to do but there have been a lot of surprise resignations.

Jason Chaffetz, I don't -- Trey Gowdy not going to run for re-election. There are a lot committee heads on the Republican side who are not going to run again. And we are forgetting as well, Paul Ryan didn't even want this job.

REGAN: That's right.

TARLOV: Remember, when he begrudgingly took in and he was like, well, I want to make sure that I can spend time with me family. So, under these circumstances when he's pushing forward an agenda that the President really doesn't have much interest in it, I can see why he might want to bow out gracefully before.

REGAN: It's kind of thankless job, right, Ned? I mean, you know, you either, you know, buy into what the President is doing, I think it's been hard for him. I think it's been hard for a lot of Republican there because they're kind of, "I don't know if I like this. I don't know if I like where it's going." And I worry, much as you do, I think, Ned, it's the swamp influence that they have --

RYUN: It is.

TARLOV: -- the ear of many corporations and lobbyists that have their own interests at stake. And so, suddenly everybody is saying, "Whoa, we have a huge trade war coming, thanks to President Trump and his administration." And so, they're fighting back against that. When we all know that if we don't start to confront the reality of what China is doing now, it's going to be our kids that are paying the price, Ned.

RYUN: Absolutely. You know, I think we're already -- China has already declared economic warfare on us. I think people just wake up to that fact. But no, you're right and, Trish, you've kind of alluded to this just now.

The interests of Corporate America in the American people, the American working class are not always aligns and the problem here that you see in Republican politics and I know even in Democrat politics, a lot of the big donors to these parties are from corporate interests. They are not aligned with American voter. So, there's no alignment between Trump with the outside devolve power from D.C., drain the swamp.

I mean, again, this omnibus bill had nothing to do with draining the swamp. It was actually feeding the swamp. It was a triumph from the swamp but it goes back to some of the structural problems with in party politics of who's actually footing the bill, who's funding things

And I tell you want? When it comes down to the down to leadership, there are a lot of people with corporate interests, special interests that are right there in your ear whispering, "You want to do this, you want next big check, you need to do this." And sadly, this is what continues to happen in D.C. year after year.

TARLOV: Yes, that is interesting, though, that you point that out about Corporate America not being on the same page as the American voter. When you saw the Republican bill with big slashes to the corporate tax rate but not to the individual --

REGAN: They gave individuals a great, great deal, too. The only individuals that --

TARLOV: -- a lot of people are not benefiting from that.

REGAN: -- we are high earner in New York and California.

RYUN: Jessica, no complaints.

TARLOV: Yes.

REGAN: But I would say, we need to do that on the corporate side. And they did give a pretty big one to the -- that's a story for another day.

TARLOV: Another segment.

REGAN: Thank you, Jessica.

TARLOV: Thanks, Trish. Welcome back.

REGAN: It's good to see you guys. It's good to be back.

Anyway, we're going to look at this because the court battle underway right now to decide the fate of AT&T and Time Warner is heating up. We're going to have some details for you next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Department of Justice is attempting to block the potential $85 billion merger between AT&T and Time Warner. They're in court today, right now.

For more, we're going to Connell McShane. Hey, Connell.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: Well, hey, Trish. We have quite a face-off in the courtroom earlier today between Warren Schlichting, is a guys and Executive at Sling T.V., which own by Dish network, and an attorney for the company Daniel Petrocelli is representing AT&T and Time Warner.

Schlichting is a government witness. He testified yesterday here in court that Turner program and all the networks' Turner control, DCO, AT&T, CNN, all the rest, that it's a must for Sling and for Dish Network. But today, there was a challenge to that. That's the real question, coming up on the screen is, are these Turner Networks really must have programming?

Petrocelli was interesting in the way he did it. He used the quote from Charlie Ergen, the founder, kind of against his own employe saying, that he had said Ergen, "CNN may and must have programming in 20 years ago but it's not anymore. Schlichting response that, "I call that negotiating in the press." And they kind of have similar conversation, Trish, about sports programming and back and forth and went between the two.

As we move now into the afternoon session as Schlichting wraps up, we expect to hear from the government's next witness in this trial, which could be a very interesting witness and expected to be a hostile one, the Turner Chairman, John Martin. We'll see if any of his past words particularly in contract negotiations can be used against him.

That still to come report back later. But for now, back to you.

REGAN: All right, interesting stuff. Connell, Thank you so much.

I have to say, it's pretty good to be back. It's great to be back in FBN. I had a wonderful week off, a vacation with my family. We went all the way to Hawaii, believe or not and I wanted to show this because this is my daughter, Alexandra, and she begged us for surfing lessons.

She's only eight years old. You may have seen her on the show. She talked about her Brownie, Girl Scout cookie sales recently. Well, she was on that surfboard. Oh my goodness.

She got up on this thing and we thought ourselves, "Are we really good parents." She is quite a kid.

The other two were not as enthused about the surfing thing, I totally get it, Elizabeth and Jamie. I don't think you could get me on one of those things either, I'll be honest. People asked me if I took that video. I'm like, "Are you kidding me? Me on a surfboard?

That will be the day. Liz Claman, over to you. Down, gosh, 109.

LIZ CLAMAN, FOX BUSINESS NEWS ANCHOR: I know, exactly. So, we have more than 250-point gain earlier gone.

END
